Notebook 23, Page Image 11; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 1r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-011.jpg

[K.B.]

1908

Sine tuo Numine

Nihil est in homine

Nihil est in⟨n⟩oxium

[E.C.]

January 1st – A Most Blessed

New Year’s Day! What it is

to be free from temporal

Control – the “tabula[?] rasa” illusion

– a space of Time one had washed

oneself with one’s own trust

in one’s will! And now one’s

supernatural year has begun

a month earlier than New

Year’s Day & one is deep in the

yearning for Humility & one’s

will finding its vocation in

God’s.

Francis comes. I open the door to

him: but fresh from his married

Paragon in Clifton he steps into

Paragon, Richmond himself –

marriage, for the time, adventitious.

He has a gifted way of entering

into the life of a house integrally

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 12; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 1v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-012.jpg

[E.C.]

Publishers in black type –

Desclée, Lefevre & Tournai

Note to Swinburne with ‘Wild Honey’

Dear Mr Swinburne,

I am tempted to ask your acceptance of my

Honey-book. With deep affection – the

affection of the aging poet for the Poet crowned

with age – I offer it to you. Of course to me

now there is no English-breathing Poet

save yourself. I, wistful for a reader,

am glad you stay with us. Michael Field.

_____

To Ld A. Douglas. [ He had returned Poets.

Dear Lord Alfred, I thank you for the courtesy

of re-enclosing the M.S.S.

Waking in a new language in a new

country I fear I am often clumsy in

combination & presumptious. And I am

glad you shd wish only to print what you

hold my best things.

* If either of these shd be considered of

sufficiently high rank?

I am grateful for accorded leave to thank

you for that article that did so much to

keep us singing in the world.

*“(old” “Tide”) Michael Field.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 13; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 2r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-013.jpg

[E.C.]

Frida Thursday

Fr Green calls & Francis in the curtained-

off “Grot” creeps off⟨away⟩ least he should

startle sonnets of our souls!!

Fr Green speaks of his hepaticas

in the chestnut-roots as of

parishioners – he loves our

gold holly & green buds of

lilies – he discovers boredom

at a dinner of beef & pork for

Christmas cheer, & while

claiming sympathy, like

a sea-creature its waves,

returns nothing. Michael

mentions Wild Honey, & he

advises us to read a booklet –

say on Rome (in kindness) to

make it a little limited⟨within⟩in the limits

of manners! Well, well! What

Idealists have to hear! He himself

as a priest of the Ideal Church

endured an hour’s scolding

from the Catholic local butcher

that⟨because his⟩ meal had been got once

or twice at Richmond. We, the

Idealists of the Temple of Beauty,

must endure his accidental

remark, too accidental to

even wound with its lack of

ableness of feeling.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 14; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 2v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-014.jpg

[E.C.]

Both deep in the Catholic Fold, with

the great word on its doorway, Pax.

⟨Yes,⟩ We are learning to walk, to

talk, to grow on a New Earth,

with our eyes on a New Heaven!

So it has been with us, &

marvellous the life we are

children in. Francis Thompson’s

Hound of Heaven (a beautiful,

unequal poem) catches a little

of the urgency by wh : we reached

deliverance – our mystery,

our strong Silence that avails.

Trouble with health & January

before us, always a sad month

to us – but every part of the

year means so much to us

now, & consolation keeps

pace with discipline . . .

So touching! Old Mr Higgott

writes in his celibate devotion

to Michael

“Your simple old Man,

Sam [????] Higgott”

Sweet old farmer – he had in the

days of my childhood at Newton

a look of perpetual advanced

years, & over the Chasm between

then & now, he signs himself

from the green fields on the Dove,

“Your simple old Man”

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 15; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 3r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-015.jpg

[E.C.]

Saturday

Our copies of Wild Honey in the

vividly green cover arrive

so timely. In Epiphania Domini

Oh, joy! We read Lauds

with its mad antiphon to

the Benedictus, telling how

Christ washes His [????]

Jordon for His Spouse ⟨in Jordan⟩ how the

Mages run with gifts to the

Feast, & the water is made

wine for the happy guests.

The Church is mad for joy!

Such a smell of frankincence

– it lies on the air heavy as

the ice lies on the motion of

the river. – And gold, incongruous

offering to the babe in the

Manger, like all inexpressive

signs of joy, comes from

very far.

Michael writes to Fay –

My dear Painter,

But the Caves is [ now ) “attractive” –

And the book comes for the

Feast of the Epiphany. Glad are we

to have one, so wise a man, to

read its signs.

And, Painter, remember! This book is

Henry’s; what is excellent in its

ordering & distribution is Henry’s.

Attribute also to Henry all that

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 16; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 3v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-016.jpg

[E.C.]

⟨is⟩ comfortable in the Art; kindly

also attribute to Henry all

that you do not approve in

the range or chapter of

the Emotions. And I stand,

a Mopsus, behind the heavy

sonnets on October –, November

& December – all the ‘Nature’-

things I should never dream

of reading, & for my sins have

written.

For your sins, my dear Painter,

you might in penance compose

a “brief list of those poems

you like best.” And, when

the freezing Thames is frozen

you will skate down

to Paragon.

Michael

Epiphany Sunday

Oh strange! Can it be that all those

trumpets of whitest substance

that alone on the High Altar

& round Christ’s Dwelling-

place are shouting forth their

Epiphany triumph, so that the

Ears hear with the sight of the

eyes, & the band of lilies are

veritably heard – Can it be

they are our lilies? –And that

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 17; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 4r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-017.jpg

[E.C.]

young priest, firm & white in presence,

can it be he is my Confessor?

And last Epiphany, we were

strangers before the Altar &

its Ritual!

Goscommon speaks – with the

gentle independence, as of

a lily giving perfume,

that is the quality of his

little sermons – of about

the Mages’ gifts, as the

three Christian graces of

almsgiving, prayer, & penance.

Very austere he is over penance

– the myrrh of the Tombs.

I hear the threatening Echo of

the Monastery “Retreat” in

the stress he lays on “the Guard

of the Eyes”. Ah, as Fr Sam.

said, it is by looking into the

eyes characters are read –

Christ looked thus: it is by

the eyes set on Nature & all

the beauty of man’s creations

& on man in all he does &

is – it is ⟨only⟩ so ⟨ [????]⟩ ⟨can⟩ the great poet

expounds his Penticostal gift!

How hardly shall a poet

Enter into the Kingdom where

Monks & priests are the Ministrants!

Yet God give us such Epiphania –

& manifest [????] as Catholic

poets in Spatia Cantatis!

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 18; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 4v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-018.jpg

[E.C.]

Michael goes to reedy Isleworth

& I to the Vineyard to see the

Host enthroned for Exposition.

Goscommon preaches again –

almost the same sermon of

as last year, when I wept

with terror & joy as I felt that

the Star was guiding us, but

we did not quite know

where the Manger was or

how we should get past

Herod safely.

Francis keeps by the blazing fires

of our White Room: he reads

‘Wild Honey’ as if it were

made from bitter flowers, &

only dwells on lyrics & poems

apart from Zermatt & the

Palace – on which the silence

tingles with self-consciousness;

yet the cloud is only gentle after

all.

We creep up to visit the blessed

Sacrament among the candles

& flock of lilies – that is

the Star, the whiteness of the

Light of the World above us by

which all our life’s journey

is led now.

The Vespers sermon (by Jewel) &

benediction are long, & the

pulse of joy is weak.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 19; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 5r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-019.jpg

[E.C.]

Epiphany itself

The symbolic star shines out in

the black-cold Church.

Francis leaves us – moved on

showing that the years do

not touch the old feeling, That,

as Sappho preached – in

this [????] relentless as ^⟨to the extreme of?⟩ the

Church herself – love is as

hard as gold.

This visit has been a beautiful

thing – what is more beautiful

than the mellowness of a

human love? And when heaven’s

sunshine has lain over it, &

the sweetness is due, not only

to ⟨an⟩ inward season of fidelity but

to the beams of visiting light

as well – that love becomes

a sacred charity, abimo

pectore, & one gives it . . . of

Sappho’s gold, of the Altar’s

frank-incence, & the sepulchre’s

spice – in little handfuls from

the Wise Men’s Kingly offerings.

I never knew another man like

Francis for Embracing unanimity

in the bond of a home. He

is there, pleasant as a quiet beam

& he goes as quietly, so that regret

is more subtle than mere missing –

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 20; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 5v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-020.jpg

[E.C.]

It is a secret one has with one’s

own atmosphere.

We read the Matins of ⟨Die iv. Jufrer Octavan⟩ Epiphany

– Ah me! Large-voiced Sr.

Gregory says the Truth there

“Ma prima vero nobis aliquid Magi

innunt, quod in reginam suam

per aliam Vienne revertmutus” –

Another way back to one’s

self & one’s life! All the

road must be new – that

is the bitterness of Conversion,

that is why Christmas

was so intolerable – we were

seeking wildly for traces of

the old path –& our camels

were making the only possible

path with each new treading –

but we, foolish, took them

from their direction to

transe-verse & Zig-Zag wandering.

Michael.

The Visitation of Della Robia –

It is It. The Extreme beauty of Christ,

the austerity of the desert-prophet, in

these 2 figures. Oh! to write like that!

Never about things – close, gripping their magic.

Oh, oh, oh!

Christ among the Doctors (Duccio) That Mother rejoicing

her Son is about His Father’s business – how inscrip

-tural, how Catholic & Imaginative. It must needs

be – the imperative of the Imagination, how Essential a mode!

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 21; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 6r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-021.jpg

[E.C.]

Jan. 14th.

The Famous Little Fellow writes –

My dear Michael,

“The Wild Honey is full of En-

-chantment. The poems I

taste in hurry are as marvellous

miraculous & familiar as the

bell to the bee. There is a

glorious busy hum like the

sound of invisible things

in the Italian summer. The Phoenix –

the lion en pension – The Cherry

Song – & the rest today after

your letter is gone. The decoration

is rightness materialised.”

John Gray.

Francis writes –

“I very much enjoyed my visit, &

took especial delight in witnessing

the new happiness into which

you have both entered & I

remain with many thanks &

best love to you & the ‘lovely,

brave’. always your most affectionate

F.B.

Thursday

There is a sign of returning sense –

‘Jewel’ comes suddenly to read

the Breviary with Michael –

strange! Michael & the queer

little Chafer-priest, with his exquisite

voice for the carriage of Latin cordial

& agreeing with Each other!

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 22; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 6v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-022.jpg

[E.C.]

Friday 10th

And Gosscommon comes again, &

in his old place the [????] of

Christmas . . . spite of the strain

about the season he acknowledges,

he likes Christmas & “Adores

Mince-pies” – he says so with

the dark fervor of a hierophant

before a rite in ⟨his⟩ eyes – smiling

boyishly. Then he instructs

me in the network of

Commemorations & Suffrages.

He has been writing a paper

on the relation of Christ’s death

with⟨to⟩ the times of the Pasque –

& doesn’t he take pride in Expounding

it! We are exemplary patience

all the time, it is so charming

to watch the child’s serious-

ness on the ⟨ [????]⟩ simple face & the

short frowns at a difficulty,

like broken twigs in front

of a baffled, impetuous form;

this head is so toiling behind

the [????]⟨seriousness⟩⟨energy⟩ & fret of his eyes!

Saturday 11th

And, at last Fay comes “to praise

‘Wild Honey’” He wins a welcome

by being the substitute for an

awaited Lady-Caller . . of course,

there is acclamation! And he

steals back, as a happy dog intending

to make himself at home with his

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 23; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 7r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-023.jpg

[E.C.]

bone, into the hall, – returns

with the valley-lilies, a spray of

vermillion flower from a

greenhouse –& the bronze

‘Tragic Actor’. He wants it

placed where the Tragedies

are written. While with

lifting hands we play with it,

or reach water for the flowers,

Fay “thaws’. Indeed he looks

exactly like our Pan of

“Frozen Rushes” – a withered

God! He declares he must go

back to Shannon. Michael

steals out & creates a dinner

with Mrs Drew; then back

to say “You stay – you dare

go back to Shannon!” And

the little Proteus, at most squeaking

at the grip ⟨the voice⟩ complains “I must,

I must” & touches a fortunately

uncharged electric bell.

“It is no use calling up the

kitchen – for Mrs Drew sent up

word ‘tell Mr Ricketts, I want

him to stay’.” Then the contrariety

makes for the door, firmly held –

then wails for a telegram

to be sent . . . I send it “Am staying

at Richmond to dine. Alas!”

We suggest he can go after dinner –

He stays on calmly till after 10.

Subjugated Proteus – turned to prophet

from rebel! Yeats made to Fay

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 24; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 7v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-024.jpg

[E.C.]

the shrewd remark “You are

always in a state of rebellion

against yourself”.

The psychology amazingly deep!

Yeats touches the secret that

haunts Fay with peril. His

gifts are so wonderful, so

manifold, the achievement

so brilliant & distracted: lovely

things like the Leda, destroyed

as they touch harmony –

& then, in companionship,

the lack of peace one feels

with him – the “strain of

the stuff”! He comes, but he

never leaves happiness behind –

gifts in bronze, or book, or

flowers & memories of luring

moods: pantomime, that enthralls,

persiflage, narrative of impressions,

thoughts expressed by swallow

rapidity of speech! – All these

gifts; but joy or peace never

among them!

While we dress he goes out for

Cigarettes, & then, as in the old

days of⟨with⟩ Bernhard in Rome, the new

book is opened by him & ⟨another copy⟩ by me,

while he indicates his choice

or dispraise.

He adores ‘Pan Asleep’ – the scourging

in the ivy-grot . . . The last line is an

achievement; it gives the sense of an

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 25; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 8r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-025.jpg

[E.C.]

‘open window’ – that sense is rather

wanting in the Sonnets generally.

They are a little too “close” – too

locked at the end. He does not come

for “Chariclo”, but esteems the

“Lament for Cheiron” very beautiful

indeed: – He pauses – “a most

beautiful poem”. Then, he lights on

Penetration. Onycha has very

beautiful things in it, though as a

whole he does not now1 care for it.

Frozen Rushes mentioned – joy in

Armour. The Winter Aphrodite will

be praised. Embalmment, very much

liked, & Lord Love & Forever greatly

liked. The Baudelaire translation

very good. He acknowledges characteristically

that the Train of Queens (He once praised

it immensely) worries his nerves

because Cuchlain is mentioned!

He finds my little God of Silence beautiful,

Nests in Elms & White Madness both

highly commended; while the Morning

Rains is perhaps, next to the Aspic,

the loveliest poem in the book. But

the Aspic! – he has no words to use as

weights to measure his praise! Then he

strongly admires Listening. The surprise

from him, is, that, unlike Francis

who kept tomblike silence over the

Zermatt sonnets, he proclaims them

the finest in the book, simple, with

such sureness & dignity. One lifts one’s

lamp high to Art & to Beauty while

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 26; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 8v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-026.jpg

[E.C.]

Fay in his love for Art & Beauty

lauds these poems to the dead

Rival. He mentions ⟨The ⟩⟨Torrent,⟩Possession,

Falling Leaves (most beautiful of all)

The Forest, Burial, High Mountain

Flowers, Mouldering Leaves, & last

Parting –

We had been drawing keen breath

about the doorways of the heart

as he approached the end of

the book. Michael made a little

prayer –

“And after Parting, I dislike all

the rest”.

After all, the Rival of the Longer

Allegiance has long been dead –

I live, & Chow still lives

for Painter about the Rooms

of Paragon. Our poems are

dismissed . . . Old Ivories,

Unity, Palempsest, In Leash

to the Stranger . . . well the

great Crucifix at the End is

included in the same distaste.

We made no comment, & Fay

continues that his praise

of the poems has been restricted,

because he cannot recognise

them by their titles & they have

only been read once. He admires

the book much more than his

words have expressed, owing,

to his slowness of eye (like

Michael, he can never find his

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 27; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 9r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-027.jpg

[E.C.]

places)

We feel the praise a little set,

somewhat lacking in final

generosity, as so often with

Fay’s abstract praise. Four

words of the Famous Little Fellow

are warmer. He⟨Fay⟩ cannot leave

the Creator’s ice-cave for the

Reader’s happy grove, or

stream-bank of mint! There

is the fault! With all his

multiplicity of gifts, his Protean

moods, Proteus can never

become a Man – he is always

sea-beast, or prophet-wonder-

worker in Semblance of a

man – in semblance only –

never never the heart-compelling,

heart! gratifying human creature,

near to us with appeal &

familiarity.

After dinner (an impromptu of

Tomato Soup, Cutlets, Damson Tart &

Cream, Olive & anchovy Savoury, & Excellent

Claret) Fay takes up the Academy &

finds a skit by Bobbie Ross on a

Bernardian Morellian frightening

away its family ghost from a

discredited Vandyke. This Fay

reads, his mouth full of laughter

as a child’s, if, goody-stuff. The

is ⟨skit⟩ only fairly brilliant & here & there

neatly hits the Morellian craze, but

Fay laughs packing his mouth with

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 28; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 9v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-028.jpg

[E.C.]

Without⟨the laughter⟩ – his eyes vily with it –

his face becoming positively

naȉve with malice in a

state of pure enjoyment – Breathless

he reads; then a giggle [????] in

his voice, & it is let [????]⟨ [????]⟩ ⟨go⟩ round

the boles of fantastic trees, or

sylvan rocks where unearthly

fun bursts from satyrs.

Again he reads, stoops of over

his delight & becomes an

Eros stealing honey & filling his

mouth with it, till he gets a

string & the honey runs out on

a little scream. What elemental,

baby-boy pleasure in this man

at the secret-springs of nearly

every intellectual movement

of the time!

Then we turn somehow to Baudelaire

& I bring the handsome vol. he gave

Michael. “And I gave you this!” –

Michael gives⟨shows⟩ him Plantagenet

rage – oh he sees the wild Broom

toss, the golden lightnings, that

would be equal to killing the

Lord Abbot of Glastonbury!

But the ship of a Proteus dares

to persist & to repeat he had forgotten.

Then with a twilight fall of gravity

– that solemn heritage he gets from the

south – ⟨–⟩⟨ [????]⟩ he reads Baudelaire’s

Angel making appeal, & whispers with

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 29; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 10r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-029.jpg

[E.C.]

sound of a cat drinking cream in

his voice “je ne veux pas” – terrible

sound the over the words that

should be positive to justify the

sound & one unnaturally

festive with refusal!

And he reads of the light⟨night⟩ creeping

in on the hospital.

One of Baudelaire’s most

Catholic gifts in his charitable

setting of the wretched in light

& air that are benign, however

outcast what they touches[?].

Baudelaire is far more tender

than Keats when he is great. –

More so than Catullus, who

is a heart’s league beyond Keats.

Then in the midst of the

twilight mood, Fay speaks of

his painting – it is as if

another held the brush; the

irresponsibility frightens him –

he never knows that he

will express what is in his thoughts,

he is startled, he cannot tell

why the thing has been done. In

sculpture himself he expresses

himself; it is his will, & what

he would he does: he can

foresee his effects, provide for them,

attain them. He is sure there,

while uncertain on canvass.

“Why the devil should I paint the

Resurrection?” It is moving to

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 30; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 10v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-030.jpg

[E.C.]

watch this creative face

questioning the genesis it

must look on, without

knowing if it is good.

Genius when it speaks in

its privacy always subjugates

me with a devoutness

that would bear what has

been exposed to the Catacombs.

I wanted to light tapers

& go out of the Room.

Instead, the time came for

Fay to go. 2

A disquieting thing he said to

Michael à propos of “Wild

Honey” –“You are heartless,

& I am shameless”

I did not hear it said – so cannot

conjecture its intonation

nor fathom it.

Just with his⟨a⟩ remark, when

speaking of Bobbie Ross, that

he gave unsparing portraits

of Michael – the assertion

of two privatives in one

audacious phrase gives

room to anxiety.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 31; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 11r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-031.jpg

[E.C.]

As soon as Michael reaches her

bedroom she is violently sick &

ill. Long she sits by the

fire, drowsy with exhaustion.

At last between two & three

we sink asleep.

Tuesday

At the end of the Mass, the server

takes away the Napkin from the

altar-rails & extinguishes the

lights awaiting the 2nd Mass,

Gosscummon’s. I watch – by

a double action lights are

extinguished in my heart. The

sense of preparation gone

has never made such a

void in my spirit. I am

anxious, but just by the

anxiety, with the thought of

a “call” to the sick or dying

as the reason for the

quenched candles.

Wednesday

And the white card on the Church

Door continues today there will be no

second Mass.

My tears run through my veil & my

hands. I am sure something has

happened to Goss. And I think of

his little sermon on Sunday

evening as if it were his last.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 32; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 11v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-032.jpg

[E.C.]

It was a beautiful little sermon

on the Ways by wh : we could lose Christ

(as His parents lost Him) & find Him

(as He was found of them) – Losing Him

by our fault in Sin & as a trail by

Dryness; finding Him in the

Sacraments of Penance & the Eucharist

within the Temple of God. Goss was

moved & moving over “Dryness” & told of

St. Cath. of Siena who was left by Christ

for some days “Jesus, why didst thou

leave me?” she asked her Divine

Lover. “Katharine, I was by⟨with⟩ Thee

all the Time!” The candour of real

Spiritual Experience, the warmth under

the difficult sentences, the lifted,

gentle brows, the persuasion, not

of the orator, but of the child

or animal or simplest kind

of saint made my young

Confessor a power; & when I

thought misfortune had fallen

on him, he became a sweet

memory with rain all round

it.

What relief – rather like that of a

surgical operation – to find &

open a note from him!

Yesterday he fell on the ice & cut

his head over the right eye, with

the result, – bandages & seclusion.

He can read, but the Breviary is

rather a tax on shaken attention.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 33; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 12r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-033.jpg

[E.C.]

The January days of pain & discouragement

go on. Thursday I have to come

out of Church through the clawing

darkness of the semi-swoon of

gout. I half-see the Elevation in

a cancel of mist.

Friday I remain in bed – the hill

is not climbed to the Vineyard.

But the day suddenly veers into

an eager loveliness rare in the

very first spring. We remember

we had praised a visit to the Palace,

& by cab & train & cab reach it.

But the Palace if fireless, flowerless

– & the Masters just gone away.

The good House Keeper – a tiny

creature, with eyes that have

the timid sprawl of jelly-fish –

telephones here & there over

or along Bond Street. Vain!

So a fire is lit, &, as it burns

reluctantly, we are taken

into Shannon’s heated studio,

where tea is brought.

We prowl, we prowl . . .

In the Drawing Room “Wild Honey”

almost touching the Egyptian &

New most-beloved Gods & goddesses

– Two new ones – no, a goddess & a

priest – by the side of the new book!

Michael’s black opal by her Sicilian

amber – a really lovely thing with

the sliding blue thrust over it there is

[Page]

Deposition; many figures coming

out of the formlessness & void by

men as trees seen through the

But what is this?

Before our eyes a most lovely idyll

of Charity! A valley full of

compassionate light, drawn about

a group – the naked stranger, held

up by the tender force of the Samaritan

on the back of the ass, who has

been allowed to pause & drink

the stream he crosses. The conception

of that group in its wholeness of

action, & that action the

unity of a double tenderness to

man & beast, passes anything

I have seen in painting as

far as design is concerned.

And the sweet lights, as from

the Heaven that is a simple

Pearl, round the group consecrated

by a virtue at its loveliest!

Oh, but it will not stay – it will be

blotted out, as that lovely

blue Leda. O cruel, mocking

Demon, that makes Fay blot

his lyric pictures, & only allows

us to be “rich in the simple

worship of an hour” – then the

wet smear & creations of

infinite beauty vanish! I

could make Fay roll a stone

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 36; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 13v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-036.jpg

[E.C.]

up a hill day & night for

O Fay! O Satan, who standest

Saturday. St. Peter’s Chair.

I am so ill at Mass – I feel like

the pains of dying – negation

become an anguish –, as the

cold sweat lies on my lips, &

my eyes find their way through

Extremity to glimmering view

of the altar. As soon as I

can get home I go to bed &

there I remain till Tuesday

Evening Morning, physically

overthrown, & shame to me &

my faithlessness, morally over-

-thrown as well – not caring that

I lose the Bread of Life, the Daily

Sacrifice, sullen & negligent with

regard to the Supernatural Life . . .

In fact, three words of Condemnation

penned⟨pen⟩ me in from all blessing

Michael on Sunday goes to Isleworth

On Sunday the Cabman, being

Reply

Dear Sr. Thomas,

you cannot find Painter behind

the rhymes?

“But when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,

So, traitor, when she comes? When

she is thence?”

The thyme is “various” – one

cannot pass all the flowers, &

yet it is to one secret, cleft-hid,

stealthy, curiously ‘small &

delicate’ little binding-plant

of Basil – Thyme the fragrance

of Michael’s honey is owed.

Poet, in this you must not

blunder – you may ruin worlds.

Of course, Painter has his own

Sonnet, among the sonnets

libres, but which of the

sonnets (not included in the sets

as Longer Allegiance & that:

manifestly to ‘Old Ivories’ &c) wh :

is not concerning him.

Oh, read deeper & rectify.

In Paragon there are two

books of sonnets. From these

only selection can be made for

“Wild Honey” We are in a world

of pressmen, influenza germs &

jealousies

Dear ‘Wild Honey’ – it is its doom to

set us all “..the from” If your

heresy has spread to the Palace I

will coolly watch you burning.

Michael.

Not a trace of Fay! But this

Prophet is blind, white-blind!

Or he is as our Enemy once

called him “Cow-headed” to

make such a blunder.

And Fay!

He will hear that Berenson is

in all the Sonnets!

Inapprehension raised to the

most dangerous power!

How can the white cloud be

pulled from these eyes of

a friend who “sees not”!

Not a trace of Fay!

Not a trace of God – so before

the world that is His & that

He made, some atheist asserts

from his serious brains!

The news of Michael Field falls

like Samson’s pillars on the

priests . . . Dear Gosscommon!

I am sure it is worse than

his fall on the ice. We feel

somehow as if a wrong had

been done to him – in the

Confessional one ought to discover

one’s creature, tho’ it is so dark!

Is it a lynx or a pard? Is it not

really so: for to be a poet is not

mortal sin, though pretty nigh[?]!

When I go to Confession on Saturday

to confess that mortal anger ⟨of Wednesday⟩ (not its

cause) & all my dereliction on

toward God, from the midst of

of his having new knowledge.

– He sends me to David the

Psalmist to help me in penitence,

with a warm relenting in the

severe voice, & gives me as

O wonderful Sacrament! I who

have been so far from the Divine

came home energised by

the Divine, ready to take up the

discipline that had fallen from

me, a field ploughed for

a treasury of good grain – a

wide, clean field, all my hidden

soil exposed for light & the

breeding of light of virtue!

On Sunday Evening Goss, speaking of

And Tuesday, the real 28th – We are

it is for a poet with his freedom

of impulse to submit to the

control & discipline of the Church.

in him – if he is hurt at what he

unprofessionally regards as

lack of trust in me (He shows[?]

toward me plentiful lack of trust!)

or if he is overwhelmed in his

humility & simpleness⟨with[?]⟩at the

burthen of a penitent & convert,

who is an acknowledged poet.

It is tragical; & I shall pray

we may be drawn into peace

again. Next to Chow he has

helped me most of any creature

to the Supernatural Life; & his

“Welcome” was like the word of

an of angel, who was going to be

my guardian-Angel in the visible

world - so sure & good, full of

adoption, intimate as holiness

can make a word – so that one’s

ear is indeed a sea-shell of the

stainless & secret depths.

So glad to ease the strain of

The pond[?] makes all sculpture

look ridiculously suburban –

Fay’s wild images of Centaurs

or Laoccon & his boys look

violent in suburbia; & his

noble pietà now in bronze

is lost as[?] the noblest things

must be in vulgar the surroundings.

– They are hidden; they escape

as Christ did when he hid

from the Multitude.

The effect of this pietà is of

three supporting masses as

of hills – supporting a steep

declining valley, the heads

⟨of the hills⟩ alone as Knolls raised

above the slope of landslip.

So Christ’s body depends on

the three figures in its load:

so it falls over them, their

heads raised over it – dark little

hills of sorrow.

So one has the [????] sense

of the stretch of a high valley

downward – the Knolls congregated

[Page]

in triangle – the body of each

[Page]

The Gallery!

One thing of aesthetic value I

are giving all the warmth of

How the mood after sundown

work of art – & oh, how beautiful

the browns & neutrals all

the colours of poppy-seeds. One

could rest in the sight of this

picture; we could be laid asleep

by it maternally.

Ah me!

When once discipline has been

one finds nearly everyone round

one in the rough.

Yesterday Thursday Jan. 30th

Michael went to St. Dominic’s

Priory to see Fr Vincent.

He had written Jan. 26th

“My dear child,

I am grieved to hear that Henry has been

imprisoned from the faith Yet it

is not untempered regret, since I

feel sure she has been busy

distilling honey from the bitter

Passion flowers. As you know

mountain-heather – one of the

bitterest herbs yields the sweetest.

But – you know what honey

is & where the sweetest may

be found – & have found it.

The other day in reading the office of

the “Conversion of St Paul” I was

almost overthrown by the phrase

Elegit Dominus Virum de plebe;

et claritatem visionis aeternae

dedit illi (Chapter for Vespers)

What tremendous eloquence this is

the soul that penned the “Envoi” . .

to Wild Honey will understand it.

“The Lord picked out a man from

the people, and gave him sight

of the Vision Everlasting”

I should be free on Thursday

morning”

Yours sincerely in fear[?]

Vincent N’Nabb .O. P.

Fr Vincent

The Union with Christ is six times

closer in Purgatory than it can be on

Earth.

Oxygen, just after it is created, has the

most intense life: so the soul

after death. Probably it will exile

itself as it approaches the light of

the vision. You yourself, for the

Love of God, are making . . for yourself

a purgatory. You are giving

yourself pain.”

Speaking of Candlemas & the humility

______6

Of Jan. 28th We had the Mass of Thanksgiving

at 8.30 this morning & took the

Blessed Sacrament then. We read the votive

Dr Angelis, so triumphant, so glad, so full

of guardianship[?] – the animals sway[?] the

heavenly powers. How we thanked Christ for

our little Chow. It is only by my love to Chow I

am learning what my love to Christ ought to

be & shall be. If I could fear losing Him as I feared

losing Chow. If I could weep for Him, the tears

of live welling Chow has drawn; if I cd rejoice in

His love as in the golden loveliness of Chow’s, then

I should know the Love of God. So may it be, as Chow

shows the way to my God!

[Page]

Sat.

A Miss G. has been sent to call on

us by Fr Sam, as several other

women have been sent by Goss –

Dear me! They run over one’s

experience like water off oil-skin.

They have morally nothing

central, when they are not Mothers:

they do not seem, unless they

renounce the world, to make

religion central. They never seem

able to take things in except

as appearances wh : they

solidify into perf personal

interests – not even give the⟨into[?]⟩⟨ facts with the⟩⟨ir⟩

dignity, because interdependence, ⟨of facts⟩.

Women weary me – I am thankful

when they are gone to forget them;

& yet this should not be so, & if

I found women at all like our

Lady I should adore them, as I

adore the real Aphrodite-beauty

of women.

Miss G. – poor Miss G. a weariness!

No desire for any future toward

her – no relish, that is the fresh

prophecy of Desire.

Candlemas

We missed it last year – it is the last

of the Church’s Celebrations we

shall go to for the first time.

The Candles – how shall

Little “Jewel” with his sense

The Nunc Dimitis – what it is

to a Convert, to one who has not

seen death, till God’s

Christ has been seen! And

to hold the light during[?] the

Sacrifice, the sign of one’s

own enlightening & of God’s

glory! We spill no grease & we

do not set our hats on fire.

We are only happy as the

little flames that soar in

front of us.

Monday

At Mass a rather bold-hearted,

healthful[?], saint-adoring Woman

– a Dominican Tertiary – whispers

the King & Queen of Portugal! They

are both dead – is it not dreadful?

One’s heart stands back before what

calm Mother-Church of Humanity

asks our love & prayers for the

dead before any excitement

over a terrible ef event.

At home we find it is not the

Queen, but the Crown Prince.

And the King of the Cochon

D’Or! –The blithe & massive &

art-loving Dom Carlos!

Well, he has died for the sake

Dom Carlos of the Cochon d’Or – a

Victim! One of the Dead, in

From high sky & ⟨from⟩ what grace in

a handwriting how young!

It flies out at you like young

leaves from their boughs! It

A thicket for Eros!

And Bernhard croaks of Senility

But joy he has written –

write at all. But then has

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 73; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 32r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-073.jpg

[E.C.]

years. So I have read of your last

Well, I have read & shall read

real bees’ work & no compound[?]

Certainly the treasure of the

It was on my pen to write

am wrong & the lyric right – it

it echoes in “through” & no doubt

is justified in other ways.

Had you lights? Had you all lights?

*

As ribbons we hung round her chariot,

We dangled or blew out on the air –

We were dusky[?] about her breast,

There we lay at command,

And then spread through the land

Multiplied on the way from the

Wheels of her chariot.

___

It is cold to us sparrows of Venus,

Recluse on the noble winter air:

The boughs are stretched forth in the sky;

It is cold & even

On the bough, on the stream,

We company in the boughs the sparrows

of Venus.

Thursday Feb. 6th

My Second Visit to Fr Vincent.

Michael takes me to the Priory – I

am shut in a waiting-cell

without a fire: then a Lay

Brother, with the manner

of a nurse to the Spiritual

Physician soothes me “He

will come to you now directly”

& he gives me a cell with

a fire, where I study a photograph

of the Community – Vincent

toward the centre, a creature

of a different sphere, with heart-

shaped stain of hair on

his brow, like an ink-stain;

& features conditioned by

Pentecostal Wind & the torture[?]

of conflict even a wind of

the Spirit strikes with

arrows[?].

The door seems driven open . . .

Vincent in his scrubby flannels;

Vincent, a presence bowing

the Cedars like his God – for

his holiness, his refinement,

as refined gold bow one down.

And there is something of

the prophet in the worn-down

face & in the eyes, cloudy[?]

impersonal, as chrysolite

We turn to speak of the Classics[?]

[E.C.]

Feb. 22 nd –

All the space between the 6th & 22nd!

What have I been doing?

Perhaps it is that I have been absorbed

in the greatest change that has

begun or can ever begin in life –

the reception by the Spirit of its

Daily Bread – the pledge given

to the Supernatural Life that

the Child gives when, weaned

it first begins to feed on what

will support its natural

life. I feed for the Ideal Life

every day – & the growth, &

the strength! A force is in me

I was awaiting: but it only

comes if one eats & drinks of

one’s God as one eats & drinks

for the preservation of one’s Earthly

life. No wonder that in the

Secret of the mystery the one

prefigures the other. The force

in me is as the clean robustness[?]

of health, a very folly of resurrection

from the food of Heaven.

I must cease to try – I

cannot put into words this

mettle[?], this intoxication that

yet is steady as an unfailing

element of the spiritual

world – seedtime & harvest shall

never fail there to make this

food, to store this wine.

Thursday

Goss comes, his visit yesterday

When I apologise for being so late

from there!” – one’s very[?] voice

And we talk of the superbly

effective picture – the novel

flowers painted with enjoyment

as choice means to a[?]

decorative whole quite

unusual & convincing by

its ease. The sweep of the figure

in blue & the beautiful head

under the rule & governance

of the Round Mirror quite

gloriously compels victory.

[E.C.]

Monday Feb. 17th

A card from Fr Green ‘from scented

Corsica. The whole air is full of scent

& Corsican is true to its name. There

are fields & mountains covered with

all that is sweet. It is warm as

June. There are whole fields of almond

blossom, violets, narcissus & gt.

hedges of roses & mimosa.

I shall be home for next Sunday.

There are hundreds of dogs here &

children dressed in black.”

Subtle Fr Green – if Corsica is true

to its name he wants us to be

true to Isleworth . . .

And we went – but the

meeting disappointed.

This energetic priest is inapprehensive[?]

as a cat – His yellow[?] eyes

soften at a caress in the voice

– they bring no gifts. Those

who cannot be flooded

with others’ personalities

always strike others as

shallow as having no force

to rise up – ⟨& take ⟩⟨possession[?]⟩. Of course this is from

the point of view of others’

These natures draw others

as tributaries – a whole neighbor

-hood may be their watershed.

[E.C.]

March 13th

Nearly a month silent!

Our household has broken up –

Mrs Drew gave an account of her

health – more from a wildness[?] that

was tired of control. She was a

pleasant blustering presence, like

a wind, as unstable &

without any lingering when

she went – a thing that ceased

like a wind. Old Music[?] feels

quiet now she does not crumple[?]

his ears[?] or ask him a very

gale of questions: yet she parted

from the old dog as if he

were a feather & not a

dog. But the hard blue sky of

this cheery wind will be missed

by Michael, who was not teazed[?]

by it as I.

Alas we have not held our maids

to their duty, & the little Lar of

Paragon has a grimy face under

his bits of box-tree garland.

And Lent has begun. We tried fasting.

I had to give it up in the Confessional

on Saturday. Michael has been visited

with Colic of viperish quality, ⟨as⟩ when

the viper gathers up the interworking

folds of itself to strike out. And

here we are pick-nicking in our home

Notebook 23, Page Image 105; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 48r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-105.jpg

[E.C.]

giving me the right to benefit by any

Sin & Thought is when the

The light of the glory of each

temptations figure themselves

before the Holy Presence. They

are resisted by shoving in screens

between them & attention – but

they return hour after hour.

Michael suggests holy water &

prayer out of a solitude – I score

my brow with a cross of holy

water & implore that I who have

had such suffering since I entered

the Church may be spared these

vain, delusive images of thought.

They have been exiled from that

moment, driven away as by a

renewal of baptism – exiled as bad dreams.

[E.C.]

When Goss comes again I treat

my torment as a swarm of

bad dreams created as bad

manners often are by nervousness –

he does not understand at

the contracted brows force

Goss shows his old anxiety

to make me avow happiness

I will not avow it. I have

never been so unhappy.

“Oh, Father, the precious things

don’t make me[?] happy – not

my Art! . . and great affections

do not make one happy.”

He becomes gravely concerned

to find what strain[?] Confession

puts on me – &, of course,

persuades me to confess to

anyone, as the Church demands –

“though it is ⟨quite⟩ natural you

should choose one to help

you in the supernatural life.”

O Gosscommon! If he would

be himself & not try tactlessly

to “help” me! If he would be

simple, if he would show

the tenderness of his “Welcome”,

he could be the Ambassador

of his Lord to me in a moment.

Then at the next Confession, with the

Since this Confession it seemed as if

Goss drew quite away from me.

The hard black olive-shaped eyes

were scarcely aware of me: I could

not pray for him my undesired prayers.

I have been restive & resentful

more or less since.

[E.C.]

TumbleDown Dick Inn – Farnboro.

_________________________

We drive to the Abbey in the coldness

& damp of a March morning.

No congregation – one odd man

in blue & green who stands where

we always kneel in the Mass –

one woman – we alone communicate.

Such an ordeal to rise & face

the whole Community – Silence

falls . . . It seems as if Creation’s

Chorus stopped that we two

might be fed of Heaven. – the

woven sung Mass pauses,

the shaven heads remain[?] un-

cowled – The Confiteor is said

for our sins, the Indulgentiam

said, the precious treasury

unlocked; & then, as from a

high refuge from the Mountain-

heights of the blessed Trinity, a

gift is brought & given under

the light of a solemn candle.

That pause for our God to

come down from his Majesty to

us – to His two Poets who were

strangers to Him a year ago! It

is a wonder the terrible condescension

does not send us in our mortality

– but the events of Transcendant

Mercy quiet & confirm by their

transcendence, that cannot be

withstood even by humbleness.

I felt as one might dimly

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 112; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 51v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-112.jpg

[E.C.]

imagine a soul feels when

St. Michael introduces it from

purification into the light

of the Beatific perfection.

For us, that pause in the

great Act of Praise – for us,

the recent Converts, the

young Catholics of not

a year’s time – for

such a moment of incredible

fruition, granted so individually

to our love, we would

have come any distance;

for any shortest stay . . .

& each morning as long

as we come for it this

gift is ours! The thankful

-ness must be silence – continent

grace before the unutterable.

The old Benedictine Music

is memorable. I have never

heard such sl singing – the

perfection of the dual masses

of tone forming a whole

harmony. Paradise is

built with voices for bricks.

[E.C.]

Wednesday 18thSt. Gabriel’s Day

The same experience – & as told to Amy.

“I can’t tell you what a solemn awe-

rousing experience Goscommon has opened

to us here. The Music is a house not

made with hands for the living God & the

souls in Paradise. It is music absolutely

dedicated, humble in adoration &

therefore sublime in power. Like an

ocean of praise it breaks round the

throne of the Trinity, & there is no reason,

save a ritual one [????] that human

instrumentality is feeble, why it should

ever stop. There is eternity in the

current of sound: the River of Life

sweeps on & on with impregnible

waves & billows of praise. The

tone & masses of this music are

perfection. The old Gregorian Chant

preserved in its inspired, miraculous

beauty by the Benedictines!

Being an artist I am roundly taught

lessons of the Church no priest has

been able to clinch.

And then think what it is to receive the

Blessed Sacrament! We two His poets came

to the rail, face the whole community –

there is a silence: the great Music has

stopped ceased – O the silence! Then a

low Confiteor for our sins an Indulgentiam

– Silence again; it seems as if Creation’s

chorus stopped. Then there is a rustle as the

whole community uncowl & kneel at

Sunday. March 22nd

Amy’s Confirmation

The Sevenfold Spirit sent forth on

her in Sacrament:

Of the seven-fold gifts we find

she chiefly needs

Spiritum Sapientiae (badly?)

Spiritum Consilii

Spiritum Scientias.

Michael repines

Spiritum Intellectus (badly)

Spiritum Fortitudinus

Spiritum Scientiae

I require

Spiritum Sapientiae

Spiritum Consilii

Spiritum Pietatis (badly)

This list is our Lenten discipline.

Oh, to be confirmed Chrismate

salutis.

I want the Wisdom that can

go forth on the whole of life –

the power of endowing

others with mental virtue –

the power of lifting the

heart to Him whom my

Intellect worships.

It shows the profound difference

between Michael & me that she

specially need no like gift of the

Septinarium.

The Times notice is the truth truly

Pall Mall. Still the Times

words are very blessed.

John Gray

Tuesday 24th

We take lilies from Richmond

Michael, holding them out

He has the exquisite Benedictine

solicitude for the stranger –

a simple silver vessel of

welcome.

Our lilies are immediately given

[K.B.]

The Flower Fadeth.

Tears heard on Peter’s breath

In evening, in a field of grass:

Gray eventide, a mass

Of flower of grass & straw

Cut from sap & clinging into death,

Fashioned no more

For glory – as no more the day[?] might spring

Up through the sky, a splendour flourishing,

Erect at noon as any[?] flower of grass.

________

The Lord died yesterday.

Lowly & single, lost[?]

His wan[?] disciples, tossed

With pain of tears, have wandered wide

In the country-fields, as sheep might stray:

No need to hide,

For harvesters that mew & sing have heard

Of the far[?] city’s rumour scarce a word,

And only stare to see a stranger lost.

Gone – all of brightness, gone!

All intrepidity removed!

And Peter weeps the Lord

Whom he forswore, yet knew

As the Christ, the living, Godhead’s Son –

God gave the clue

Now[?] in the treacherous[?] grayness soon to be[?]

But⟨Deep⟩ Mid-night Peter mourneth bitterly

The sunk[?] day, the grass withering – Christ removed!

Yet he had hailed Him Christ!

Sunday

And Vincent!

The wonderful cloudy eyes gave a

scimitar-sweep to see if we were

there. The sermon’s text “Then he

began to fear & be very heavy”. I went

hot all over – ‘burns’ of anguish

all over the nerves as at some

intolerable cruelty – Vincent can

be so intolerable on the subject

of pain – he can make one’s mind

writhe as no man should.

But we escaped – though he spoke

entirely on the mental agony of

Christ, who bore every mental

torture, except actual guilt.

Vincent spoke of fear – of the

maiming fear of childhood

that often dwell on to the day

of death – he spoke of the shames

of childhood, the fringes[?] of

which are scarcely lifted in

the Confessional by the tenderest

Confessor – Love bears all fear

& all shame for its beloved. Then

he spoke of Love’s own particular

Emotions of flying from the

Beloved, the pain of leaving the

Beloved – as Christ has left the

Saints . . . all indeed of His Elected

Children, out of love & its necessity.

He spoke of the hatred Love endured

from others when it was at its work –

one of the finest sufferings possible to conceive.

she has afflicted us. Michael sees

Goss on the situation & carries it: –

when she speaks of her impatient temper

he quotes the motto of His Holiness

“Ignis ardens”.

Sunday

suffering.

Continue Tuesday of Holy Week.

When I came into His Church a

year ago a gift that was

a vow of chastity – so now

I must give another gift

for my second year & dedicate

to Him as a gift Humility.

It is so difficult! I am compacted

of pride & false humility that

disturbs the holiest balances

of Value I abhor. The Humility

Christ needs is that that fell

as punishment & redemption,

on St. Thomas, when he said

“My Lord & My God”. It is consonance

with Christ; it is confluence, it

is co-action with Christ. It is

bending one way with a precious

Influence.

In the Confessional I remorselessly

sift the Novice incident & do not

spare myself; & I review my year

in the Church, made⟨turned⟩ by my

pride into disordered & waste; save for

that tract of redemption, where

I had humbled myself to uttermost

penitence & grown my poor little

wild lilies of chastity above the

wreckage & flood-violence of

of my pride. Then I tell my

Confessor of how I am in extreme

stife strife to bring myself to give

Christ “Humilitas”, as I had given

the dreams of all the Faith[?] come

Easter Saturday

The Church’s real Easter Day when

she brings back light into the our

spiritual lives, Lumen Christi –

& light into the Sanctuary; when

she rings her joy-bells as wildly

as if to the beat of Whymmie’s

feet; when she blesses the

water, & restores the Host to

our Misery. O day, whose realization

is wonderful as the anticipation

of the other glad days we may[?]

spend! Yes, the moment of fulfil-

-ment is a mystic promise.

Easter Sunday – April 14th

My Birthday into the Church.

Yesterday my Confessor from the midst

of his toil ( persuading people to confess

& hearing their confessions ) sent me

a little awkward note wishing

me “many happy returns of the

day” – the awkwardness of inexpression.

What he feels & meditates goes into

retirement when he would express it.

I & Michael are two among the

throngs of Communicants we saw

come in wave-line after wave-line

to the the “Thus far & no further” of

the Holy Ground last year, we

being alone, perhaps in the Church,

While Michael goes to High Mass

Faith in my loved ones, that

“looked through death”, making

between them & Eternal Spring.

And between me & them

let us – and gayest through

Whymmie. Sweet the benignity

of the Immortal life, where

the dead are in Communion

with the living who so

infinitely love them.

realise that the real day of

my Reception must have its

celebration, & I forsake the

Sun Room, wondering if my

Confessor will remember the

hour when he gave me the gifts

of the Church. The Church is empty[?].

I pray Gosscommon may know

I am faithful to the hour &

pray God to plant my will

come. I then kneel exactly where

giving. In the –dark of prayer –

I hear a sound from the Sacristy

like that of the Sunday mouse – then

a door opens & the little movement

is like a crash: . . steps come down

the Church, his steps, I know them. He

seems to go to the door – he might have

locked it (he didn’t; for the sound. He did

[E.C.]

lock the sacristy side-door as on

After the sweet dark time

the Sacred Heart. Next, I settle

to read on my knees the Matins

& Lauds – so beautiful & of

Easter Day, the Day of the Magdalen.

Again the Sacristy Door opens

& Goss comes down the Church

before my eyes . . . He is come . . .

Why does he move down the

Church? What does he expect

or desire. I am mortally shy

& he does not make any

approach. So he comes do

back up the Church & goes

into the Sacristy.

When, at night, I go to Vespers

3 large candles crown my 6 –

almost exactly burnt to the

same height.

I think he put them there as

soon as I left. During the

Benediction all those candles

make together an exultant

light.

I wonder if he hoped I should have made

Confessions of the Year at the very hour of my

life-confession. Oh, I wonder?

April 30th Vigil of Amy’s Reconciliation

to the Church.

(written to her)

My Precious,

Many happy returns of the holy birthday

into the Church of Christ. . . And

there is a deeper music now in my

felicitations than there wd have

been; because I am so much more

really in the happy fields than

three weeks ago, so deep beneath

moving grass & seeds & wide

flowers & sweet leaves I am

almost hidden.

It is a beautiful thing that in the

circle of your first year you are a

full-confirmed Catholic. And

you have lighted the lights of the

Sanctuary! O little One, you

are blessed. A wish that the blessing

may increase seems so feeble:

one feels as if the blessing,

one realises as infinite, must

contract – the limitless becoming

personal & deep down in one forever.

I hope the Darwin tulips & the

wood-lilies will reach you in time

to make loved Grove House festive

for its Papist Mistress. Tulips &

lilies seem the only flowers one can

get that will travel in strength of

life.

I can’t tell you how charming Paragon

Supernatural joy & sent in

Close Kisses –

Thy Hen.

May Day

(from Michael to Amy)

Gaude et laetare, Virgo Maria!

Three candles at our dear

Lady’s altar, & at the Dominican

Priory – offered by Fr Vincent – a

mass of Thanksgiving for thee.

So sweet a May Day!

Bending over our little balastrade,

outside, we look down on a

group of fritillaries. Blue

scylla still lingers.

We greatly honor thee. Hennie[?]

has set up on mantelpiece

thy lovely portrait with

Dickie, &before it shine two of

the lovely little Italian

anemones that thou has established

in Paragon garden.

The Oxford widow has sent a

few fritillarias left over from

the blizzard!! I am writing

in my little gold-Room, looking

through pots of cherry-pie on to

the river.

We propose Kew this afternoon

regarding May-Day as, for us,

a holiday of obligation. Surely

the summer is begun. It is like

the turning out of the cattle to grass

when the door into the garden

can be left open all day: & we

can go in & out & find pasture.

Little Whymmie is with us. Dickie

My Sonnet – The first in Wilder Honey

More secret art Thou than a secret thing

That peers up on the surface of the Sea

Then reappears revolting[?] instantly:

Or as some traveller’s remembering

Of shade or light in cleft or sudden spring

Of unseen fount, or movement from a tree:

Offer a moment Thou dost pause by me

It is a token in admonishing.

Thou canst not tell gauge the appoint en[?] sent sent.

Nor of what computation it befell

Nor wherefore thou must pause with such intent

And measured steps a furlong from the well.

St. Hubert’s lovely stay[?] of breathing eyes,

Amid his antlers[?] God in sacrifice!

Benediction (often taken by one

priest, who is doing[?] the special work

of that week – & Benediction, Gosse

had intended to absent himself

from) keeps him from coming

suddenly to tea, by command of his Rector.

At the Benediction, Gosse is a

manifest rebel, who wants

cudgelling[?] – he is so naughty

in manner & bearing at what

he considers a tyranny. He

kneels by Jewel, who looks like an

old bird, wizened, restrictive,

like a haughty young thrush[?]

who has been defrauded of

his worms – those strawberries!

When he called I thought of

them & the vain money spent

on them!

Didn’t he kiss his superior’s hand

as a thrush goes for a snail-

shell!

Fay is going⟨off⟩ to Venice – “desolated!”

Michael writes – ⟨No letter from Fay – ⟩

Beloved Painter,

It is a hideous little disappointment

& the latter rains with Michael

….

This is one of the loveliest of springs

to the eyes. The happy[?] trees

look back from Nature’s breasts

& laugh.

In Italy, I am a little afraid of

Shannon’s bones. Good greeting

to him with health. And to

you all those afflictions despairs

indignations wonderments

convulsions[?] & confidence that

will make you more Painter.

Wont[?] you go a little further to Sicily

– where there are the Sicilians?

I was beginning to want to be back in

Lent again. And, in part, my prayer

is answered.

One must celebrate the May – In a

most beautiful way the leaves

are come out, with a generous

types in the Invisible.

The trees that are not

that are The flowers

Notebook 23, Page Image 197; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 94r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-197.jpg

[K.B.]

There is in Spring what passionate replying!

For tears[?] & sighs & everlasting dying

Blood is among[?] the lovely blossoms shed :

And she who clasps Adonis from the dead,

In the black marks[?] & circles purple-red

Of little springing herbs upon the ground

In everlasting sorrow is new-found.

Adonis, why

Must such warm tears fall down among

the Rocks shocks.

Will[?] lustrous flowers & flowers of ebony,

And shade[?] & shine & summer-brimming shoots?

Who is it climbs a little hill unshaded,

A bare, gray hill from which the grass has faded?

Surely she mourns one loved & beautiful;

For[?] this Void, grievous[?] place, called[?] of a skull,

She quarels in quietness most[?] Sorrowful

As one that standeth[?] by:

His death to her in every ‘hour[?]’ is found;

She hath come up awhile from Bethany,

And mourneth with the blue flowers on the ground.

Behold: if Love doth die – it is forever;

And tears are wiped away, but tears will never

Fail from their source; they drop perennial

For loveliness that disappears in hell,

For all that of one parted breath befell.

And all the lovely wind

Is wailing Music, & the spring a place

Where one is perished; & one left behind,

Seeketh, & mourneth for the Vanished face.

his hand’s evocation

in the last.

Two dove-gray nunlike

figures of Contemplation –

one kneels prostrate &

the Incarnate Christ stoops

to her as gift : then

she kneels erected fearless

& the Trinity is before her

as gift of her Courage.

A lovely Rossettian Group of

Lancelot touching Guinevere

with the touch of love for

the first time.

A group of blue robed Galatians

of St. Paul’s Company &

a free-bowed Centaur

aiming at them! Delicious glimpses!

We must spend hours with the

little nobilities & royalties of

this gold & blue art.

[E.C.]

Friday

Coming home from sitting in a

flow of air by the river we

meet Goss. He has just been

to Paragon with report of his visit

to the Bishop – & will come later

in an hour’s time. I am

throwing water over the

dazzling rose-bush on the balcony

when I discover him in the

room – He looks as if the

roses-bush were a trap baited

for him – dear Goss, with eyes as

suspicious as an animal’s.

He has really been very hard

or stupid about the Confirmation,

arranging it should be before

the Bishop’s private Mass at

8 o’clock, the day after the

General Confirmation, the

Bishop staying the night for

other business. Now such

an arrangement with fasting

& the congregation that w d

gather for the Bishop’s Mass,

is about the most brilliant

bit of Charity conceiveable.

It just passes like a shadow

of a black cloud that the 24th is

a day of Tragedy too. Still I

bow . . . Goss actually suggests I

should not take the Blessed

Sacrament, but have something

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 220; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 105v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-220.jpg

[E.C.]

“to fortify me”. Goss is desperately

wooden when a ceremony

is about. We sit there, strangers –

as if he had come from one

& he a little uneasy at the

I shut the door after him &

suddenly open it to ask for

my usual hour of Confession

tomorrow. He is at the gate –

but at my recalling “Father!”

he comes back. I feel there

is real apprehension[?] in his

eyes as he coldly assents –

“you may come at the usual

hour”.

And we have been in an intimate

relation over a year!

I understand him far more

than he understands me – but

the world in his head is so

utterly different from mine

I am soon lost – As for him,

the instant he strays from

the road he & the Church have

cut through my mind, he is

quaking on the edge of a

morass, or terrified at a

dangerous forest hung with

flowers.

I go into little Paragon Garden

[E.C.]

to talk with Michael & realise I am

the Father started on his last

I shall feel myself dedicated

to tragedy; & at woe that

my Sacrament of full

Reception into the Catholic

Church should be associated

with Zermatt & the Festa

that is to us haunted by

the mountain whispers of

sudden death, or murder,

or lingering agony.

Then too the mercilessness

of the hour for any one, with

my frail heart-action.

She can eat no crumb till

she sees Goss & arranges

something different – Either

another hour or Confirmation

at Edinborough Edinburgh.

He is cold as felzspar[?] over

the imaginative recoil from

an afflicting past : often his Irish

Temper mixes threateningly in

his voice – but Michael may manages

him till he offers to write to the

Bishop. And at this my

Anointing is left.

Trinity Sunday

*20Michael has a revelation on Humility

– that it is only safe from

self-humiliation & abjectness

when it is coupled with Faith.

This is what makes the magnificent

the expression of such living

& divine Humility. This makes

a true Saint’s humility so

wonderful, & the imposter’s

humility so hateful – The one

in veritable faith sees God

& sees[?] he cannot stand in

God’s sight – the other has

no Vision of God. It is the man

who can believe who is humble :

who has such faith that, with our

Lady, he bows to the “Be it done

unto me” of a magnificent doom.

Corpus Christi

And we hear the “Pange lingua”

sung, & we read the whole

Office – an Office of fearful

beauty a poet has packed

with every loveliness the

profoundest of thinkers has

found in this Day of the

greatest Mystery of Religion.

Such psalms, such antiphons –

hymns & lectiones all the

pouring forth of a poet’s golden

passion of apprehension.

Michael drives to Isleworth –

Thursday A Morning at our Rooms –

The rain breaks for us to go to Raffelocvich[?]’s

I meet – as I think a Jap – a little

Chinaman. He is an engineer

East in his estimate of our

universal western life “You live[?]

entirely for Time – always

eternal self-subsistence.

I hear he breaks into laughter at

a Picture Gallery.

He is a devout Catholic Convert.

I wonder if he has seen the beautiful

human fabric of Buddhism needs

the Death of a God to make it

an immortal Building in the

Heavens, or if he left the excellent

Sons of Confusius realizing at

last that Morality is not Worship.

He has tried a supernatural figure

[Page]

–a guardian Angel in front of a hut in

the cry of the sea-bird on his

in his defiance : Eros became

demoniac in ultima Thule.

Sunday July 12 th

A Dominican, F. Gabriel Whittaker,

preaches at Sung Mass.

The sermon is not original in

thought nor practical in exposition.

When we reach Whitehouse Terrace

we contrast it with one of Vincent’s

sermons. Michael is betrayed

into the Confidence that it is not

as a preacher she admires Fr

Gray whom she loves so much . .

The dear Grib protests forbiddingly.

She will not even let André

“not a word, not a word” & she

under the upper lids. She is very

said I was the most charming lady

Monday July 13th

We heard on Saturday night that the

Archbishop had delayed the

Confirmation for a ‘Trust’ Committee

till Tuesday – these Archbishops

& bishops! Fortunately for us

our nice Mrs Thom can just

give us the extra night – for

Monday had been surely settled

& we had arranged to start for

Ireland on Tuesday.

Michael grows a little sick

with Confirmation delayed.

Fr Gray is to dine with us – in

habitual rain we drive to get

lilies for our Lady’s Altar to present –

lilies & fruit for the dinner.

The lilies for St. Peter’s Lady Altar

we take, & Fr Gray loaves[?] a man,

quivering with interest that Michael

Field is in the house to show us

his Chardin, his Dining Room.

He talk of Scottish Catholic worthies

& himself shows the thistle all

round his roses the rose-bower

of his presence.

In the afternoon I call on the Raff-

Grib. – an intimate call. He speaks

most encouragingly about Conversion.

To be the real thing, to be safe from

modern, the Flood must cover

all one’s Earth, every mountain

-top must go under; one’s whole

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 263; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 127r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-263.jpg

[E.C.]

nature must be submerged. Then gradually

the waters fall – The Earth is the same

but covered with mud & strewage;

these after another while are

rich vineyards & the Earth returns

to her beauty. It is a very sad

time whom the waters of Conversion

leave the face of one’s life.

The Raff lives submerged three

years – Many of the periodicals

he most valued & values have

three years missing as record of

the Flood. Like us, like Verlaine

too, he could not read. Shakspeare

was vain – all save Wordsworth

& Crashaw. Then the flood sank –

he read Henry V – behold, it sang

true with Catholic sound.

Soon he took up everything –

but with changed evaluation

– often with new interest. He

discussed the Catholic wisdom

hidden in Göthe[?].

I must not be sad that I cannot

write, that I cannot read – I

have not been under the waters

two years yet.

This confidence was⟨is⟩ most mercifully

given – some times I feel so darkly

submerged. This friendship on

the good little Raff’s part is an

Act of Hope in my intention. It

moves my spirit to a gratitude

tenderly felt.

Sunday St. Anne’s Day – July 26 th

The ordination of Priests at the

Jesuit College, Milltown.

From a side-altar the Bread of Life

is brought to us.

Friends in the futile taudriness[?]

of the world begin to arrive, &

the bells of the Masses at the

side-altars break out on their

footfall constantly.

A long vesting[?] of the Crabbed-

looking Archbishop . . . while

the 16, who are to receive the

most awful gifts a mortal

may receive, kneel with their

candles. The faces will under a

discipline of 15 or 17 years, & under

a force of emotion we have felt

gathering in the air round the

walls & roofs opposite to us, for

the last week till it has

communicated a stress of pain

to our spirits, have the fixity

of clouds that are continent

of lightning & thunder. There is

a matter-of-factness in their

continence of thunder-clouds –

detail becomes obvious when

doom is close on operation.

Faces of victims! Not one like

the faces of other men – only the

young heads, spite of the superficial

cropping, like the heads their

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 270; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 130v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-270.jpg

Mothers bore into the world.

Heads to be dedicated that must

must[?]⟨be⟩ very dear to the Mothers

who endured a Sacrament

as victims when they bore

these sons into the world.

A moment that thrills, as when

each ordinand, as a trees

rustles forth its breeze, murmurs

“Adsum”

Then to see them fall on the Earth

-timber filled before a

Litany of Prayer to the

Commities of Heaven –

and the roar of “Ora pro nobis”

Young lions roar so for meat

These young fellows roar, as they,

for help in their supernatural

life, the life that is the starvation

of their powers of love & war

& the manifold activities

of their sex.

Like a lion’s roar, theirs

comes from deeps, upward – as

from the belly of the sea,

from caves of strong mountain

-ranges.

Then there is silence & the

ordinands kneel. That silence

is not from belong below like

the sound : it is from above –

it settles, as before snow

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 271; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 131r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-271.jpg

there is a settling aloft that

falls a miracle of peace on

what is soon to be covered

Then snow –

Now, quiet hands of the Archbishop

I miss a little of the ceremony . . .

Now the hands of all are to

watched the white imprisonment

Bandaged as if for wounds, these

palms – hands of slaves to

God, the happiest hands of

bone & flesh that they work

& fall to dust – working,

God’s mysteries here, to be

renewed in the immortal life

the hands of priests forever.

Then the stole lifted from the

neck ( that stole that is the sign

to penitents of redemptive bearing

of their sins ) – then the chasuble

of Love before & behind their bodies

giving them the protection of

their Supernatural Office of

Mercy.

Wonderfully unique to hear the

Aug 7th From Grove House – I cross to

the Jesuit College & to Fr Peter Finlay.

What steps, polish – wide open-door –

efficient welcome!

Yes, he is at home; and my wits

scuttle to the door to get out of their[?]s[?] home.

– In a few moments he enters

the parlour – as if a sword should

come & lay a steel, flat ear against

one’s lips.

No faltering words of introduction

All well[?] – I begin :

“Father I was confirmed about a fort-

-night ago . . Holy Catholics expected

me to feel that I had received the

sevenfold gifts, & I was puzzled, because

I felt no difference –”

“No wonder you were puzzled. The

whole Catholic Church is puzzled.

There are 2 schools. Duns Scotus affirms

there are not the so called 7-fold gifts –

– nothing but activities of the Holy

Ghost, moral Virtues . .

It would have been impossible

you should feel them : to feel them

would be natural, & they are super-

-natural”. – “But good Catholics

have affirmed they did feel these

gifts”.

“Then they felt them with the

nerves & with the imagination”

Of a Meeting with a Friend

My change of faith was confided, after

the first words of explanation &

understanding between us, to that

warm silence of friendship wh :, like

all noble silence, blesses in the

way of Mercy, twice-blessing each

friend who keeps it.

Journey to Ireland

Rainy – stormy. No hills of Wales,

no magic flats of Anglsea.

The ports ordered to be shut, but

we prevail against suffocation

& a waves spits at a rare[?]

leather-covered book of the

blessed Albert’s, lent by F r Gray.

In billows of wind we approach

Dublin Bay. . . . No Amy to meet

us! – checked by the weather.

My heart has damp vault-walls.

But John is kind & in his weird

way helpful. . . . The sun

visits the old gardens & the new

gardens along our interminable

way to Grove House. The dear old

place is overgrown with its trees

& looks dark, spirit-loading[?];

& the close air depresses, though

Amy & the dogs are sweetness

about the “perron” of granite &

jasmine.

Fatigue! I have never been so

to the bottom of the well

of weariness – all its mass

of water of Lethe standing

over brain & body.

To drag oneself to Clarendon St.

next morning ( Friday the 17 th ) – just

a day late for its great Feast-day of

Our Lady of Mt Carmel! The Cavernous

Church! And beautiful Brother

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 292; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 141v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-292.jpg

[E.C.]

Joachim has lost the sw[?] nimbleness

& sweep of his plasticity; & the

sharpness of the bronze features

has sunk & destroyed the

sensation of life that penetrated

the eyes fixed on them

with judgment last year.

One year in this cavern &

under religious discipline –

the pride of this wonderful

beauty is broken.

I sleep & pace the garden & its

rains & we read our Office.

On Saturday, renewed, we

not only go to Clarendon St. on

the wings of the tram, but

to White Friars also to hear

Fr Basil Maturin preach for

the Novena after the Feast of

our Lady of M t Carmel.

As St Paul was a Potent Pharasee

become Christian, Maturin is a

potent Protestant become Catholic –

both wereare penetrated with

novel truth, yet the Old Man

now & then is erected.

Maturin is deliberate & waits

till his audience is squeezed

by his silence of all noise.

The sermon is a closely-woven

exposition of the way in wh :

God has always kept the

Channels of His Revelation

separate from the world by means

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 293; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 142r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-293.jpg

[E.C.]

of specially chosen men, simply or

in groups – men with the choice

set on them that makes them

consecrated & priests.

On Sunday we go to the densely

packed Church & hear another Sermon

– much less cogent . . . a

Confirmation begins & we have

to creep out before the Mass

is continued.

On Monday we speak to a

Lady, whose noble magnitude

of body & face, in serene

light of health, spiritual &

physical, has attracted me.

Most very stout people who

are nice, are so as Trophies

of the Comfortable : this lady is

a Trophy of Vigour ; she is

a building, new-washed

with the freshness of the bath,

as with a morning-rain, that

brings roses out of her substance,

as rain will bring rose-colour

out of a stone façade.

She is huge, serene – she wd

like to live on earth forever ; she

makes the tram a sojourn in

⟨excellent⟩ climate ; she is a good Catholic –

& she tells me about beautiful

brother Joachim – really Joseph.

The boy, for , so she calls him,

is a most artistic worker in

bronze, & gave up more than £3

a week, & the art he loved to

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 294; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 142v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-294.jpg

[E.C.]

be a Carmelite. He loves trumpet –

likes as I do, & always asks

for lilies – always lilies. He is

very holy ; he is fading as his

brother did before him in the

outrageous air of sunk[?] old

Clarendon Street. In the Spring

he belonged to our world,

beautiful Brother Joseph, who

knows how to stand & kneel

& step as men did in the

Renaissance, when each one

was a subject in the realm

of Beauty & conscious of his

citizenship in hearing & gait.

So goes the week from Monday 20th

Tea drawing us, like evening

the little village-church, made

lovely by Little One : quaint dinner

I have never heard leaves so

The sermon on Monday, being the Feast of

“My dear Father,

(fragmentary recollection) Joannes

–

He replies :

My dear Child,

I cannot say why the rungs of your ladder

eyes are held & you see only the grosser

wd not have fled with them. The

Thursday August 6th

Such a beautiful day for Vincent

to go forth! We drop a tear

at Terce, when we read out

“ Cantabiles mihi erant justificationes

tuae in loco peregrinationis meae.”

He told us in the White Room at

Paragon that as he took the vow

of Profession these words filled

his soul. Oh, may he go to

Leicester, with singing as he

travels!

And it is the Feast of the Transfiguration

– the Feast of Supernatural Joy given

to support the worst of sorrows

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 308; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 149v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-308.jpg

before it fell on human nature –

What a radiant Office!

On Friday⟨Saturday.⟩ August 7th Michael goes

over to MillTown College & interviews

FrFindlay[?], that sharp two-edged

Sword of the Church. The easy

entrance to Paradise the Church

gives to those who in good faith

disintegrates my sense of

justice – It takes me more than

a week to see that though those

outside the Church receive the

penny as we inside – never

the less they have not had the

unique experience that must

alter the flavour of bliss forever

of having lived with Christ

under the conditions of this

Incarnation as He died that

we might be able to live :

that Love-way, as Browning

would say sing, had been

lost by them to all eternity.

And together with this loss

they had attained [????] conditions

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 309; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 150r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-309.jpg

[E.C.]

of invariable peril, while ⟨we⟩ had

never have chanced to be

keeping their days sheltered.

The Jesuit College has cruel

Yet I venture Benediction, &

there I meet the eyes of my

God from behind the veiling

element – I kneel detected

in every small & hateful

iniquity : I realise I have made

the Office a vain offering to Christ

through pride, impatience, hasty

words to my Love when we

read in choro. So many times

I have given what I see, now,

was rejected. I feel like the

Woman of Samaria under those

eyes. To have such exposure is

to be penetrated by healing grace

as if with a shining lancet.

Deo gratias!

The Week from Monday 10 to Monday 17th

On Monday 10th we visit our Lady’s Invalid

Sister on her parlour water-bed.

The resolute face might manage

a dairy – but the eyes in

their exhileration tell of

the awful disease of the

spine. She is absolutely uncomplaining

– remorseless to herself & therefore

hard through herself on others

who cannot reach her detachment

– she inflicts the cloister on

more worldly minds – the cloister

that, as a home, has been denied

her. Tea is made from a grand

Queen Anne set. There is a

Chippendale table rescued from

a steward in the hall – no other

objects of beauty.

It is a great privelege to bring

interest to such suffering, & to

feel it grasp hard on to one’s

sympathy.

Emily has written –

“I went to Holy Communion at

his Mass at 7 ; he was in choir

during the 7.30 Mass. Then he left

the Church. I have not seen

him since” – Oh, these partings

where no kindness can be –

save of mutual prayer!
