[E.C.]

Thursday Aug. 13th

Suddenly we make up our minds

to go to late Mass at the

Dominican Priory & seek Fr Larkin’s

Box. As he comes come down

to it, I see a man, like an

older, riper Gosscommon, austere

& saintly & limited, finely

made, with the the added grace

of sweet, convinced eyes.

He is most helpful over the

chastening of cynical moods.

Briefly, he told me to ‘offer’ what

in others distressed me, remembering

I was not responsible for them

but God whose children they

were, & then to let my judgment

fall back on myself.

He fervantly asked me to pray for

him – “not once, every day in

your prayers”. I felt the pure

stability of this Confessor as a

great comfort.

ThuFriday Aug 14th

A fast day; in a household a

Review day for Satan’s armaments.[?]

. . . . We go to a 3 o’clock Benediction

at Clarendon St. – To Receive the

Divine Eternal Blessing of Him

who died one earthly day at

3 o’clock! The hour pierces me.

And then I meditate on the

seamless Love that dies every

-day for us, takes Death as its

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 312; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 151v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-312.jpg

[E.C.]

Sacrament at the altar for

our sakes – & bears the

anguish of stooping the Divinity

to Dust while there is

a man in the Earth . .

One reels before the inconceivable

devotion of God – No wonder

the Sacrifice of the Mass is

the Absolute Revelation

of the Divine, the consummate

Mystery wanting to all

human effort to reach

God by religions. They all

offer their sacrifices & adoration

to Him – in the Sacrifice

of the Mass He offers His

sacrifice & adoration to His own

Divine Majesty as God &

for us as our priest, – laying

on our holocasts the holocast

of Himself, the Receiver of our

gifts, that Divine Love may

accept them purified & made

divine by Love’s exchange

in divine kind, transfiguring

the exchange. Oh, I cannot

put it – I adore, & give, give

from the three-barred[?]

treasuries of my heart.

All about outside & by our hearth

sweet with the silver lights

of the heavenly life they are

pursuing & are close upon now.

How beautiful is old age

that sees its God on the pier-head

of the haven where a new life

begins!

Tuesday 18th

Another letter from Fay –

“I am delighted to think that you

are publishing again. A little

portrait of a phoenix will reach you

by a near post.” . . . After a

wild scrall about the Elixir

& its inventor an unfrocked

priest . . . I think Mariamne reads

well in print . . . I like the

notion of the paper cover”.

He has seen my portrait under the

acacia –

“I do not come for the photograph. On

principle I mislike photographs

done in the open, unlike one’s past

or future, which have romantic

charm. They affect one as unwelcome

sidelights into one’s present. I have

never allowed photographs of myself

done in the open. Like a picture

or statue any real work of art

requires a carefully chosen light”.

Wednesday 19th

An old Jesuit Father, rosy, with the

idealism of worldliness his dream

apart from his office, sits by as

we dine, refusing all but coffee.

He thinks he has no spoon, the maid

brings one, & lays it on the top of the

other “Oh, oh! She thinks I am a

secular & there will be a ceremony

Monday St Bartholomew.

A meditation during the Offertorium.

Christ has borne the agony of

Time as well as its limit Death

“Let this Hour pass from me”

An Hour like that some time

in the life of everyone comes

has to be faced. Time knits

all its bones & muscles into

a fist – a single hour – &

a blow will fall. And God

the Eternal, like us, was

stunned before the descent of

that Hour . . . . The infinite Agony

of only this one Agony!

One’s soul falls prostrate –

Deus meus, Amator meus!

Carmelite mothers. Dear old

In the old body there is a

a Seraphic Child of the New

Jerusalem, though far away[?]

behind her convent bars.

The other Mother is no longer

Mother Superior. “She has had

This word of the Incarnation brings

A brief survey of our Return

A dreadful crossing of the ocean – almost

delirious with extremity . . . The

weary pilgrimaging in the little ‘special’

train to Leicester, casting sparks over

wayside stations with unbelievable

names. The Wyvern utterly

commercial[?] & kind . . . The 7.30 Mass –

the gt. Prior in the dank[?] provincial Church

with one or two Fathers . . . The Lay Brothers

that look like Pariah dogs – 2 poor

overworked fellows housed in

dens! – Then the meeting in the

dirty room. Michael left with

Vincent, while I stroll round the museum

of long-ago local bones . . .

Then the burst of a thunder-storm –

swells of lightning amid gray rain,

& Michael in Holy Cross Church at

Confession! The Prior leaves her to

her fat – I send a cab.

After that, my time with Vincent – two

of the hours of my life. How we

talked, as if we were children of the

new Earth unfettered, supremely

intimate. His hopes for us are terrible;

he is afraid of them as he confidently

utters them . . It was not in the least hard

to tell that grave face the birth of one’s

soul . . . And at last that desolate

yet sublime parting with the friend

who is a priest – the prayers for

each other before the altar; no look, no

word of earthly parting & farewell.

[E.C.]

The journey to Cromer through an England

to make one howl – only[?] we recited the

Office. We get out of train – put our 7

boxes into cloak-room – think of

taking a cab to drive round, hear the

fare will be 5/- an hour! Refuse!

We hate the look of the place, country,

sea, the extortion, the wild air of

empty pleasure-seeking in the poor folk

taking the thing impossible to us – holiday.

Is there a tram to any spot known

to us? Yes – Peterboro’. So there & then

we remove the 7 packages after

only 5 minutes’ rest in cloak-room.

The sturdy English porter admires

decision & helps the madcaps. The guard

in a wonder at such distinguished

volition puts us (3rd) into 1st Class.

Through the rain, & the cows of

old England we reach Peterboro’ . . . We

can go on & reach London at 8. We

have had no meal all day – but we

go on, forgetting our boxes will descend

without us. We seem as much to be

driven home supernaturally as

Adam & Eve were driven into the

Earth from Eden. We suspect[?] Vincent’s

prayers – He had manifestly

anathematised Cromer, for some

reason. At King’s X, long agitating

bother over lost boxes. Rain in sheets.

Every hotel full. We are turned away

from 6 or 7. In desperation we drive

to Waterloo on our way to wake up

the shuddering[?] Maxwell in Paragon.

Sunday of the Congress

Beloved Emily,

And the Martyrs’ blood on

the altar to-day is His blood. How

much more precious now it is

dishonoured. – I was rebuked so

sharply in my prayers This morn,

– & later with St. Peter – to put up my sword.

But really how nice it would be

if these who seek the young child’s

life were dead!

I think of our dear Lord as

like that dear Babe held up &d

safely by the policeman[?]“[?] He trusts

Himself to us so – & I grew to love

Him softly – with the tenderness,

the compassion with wh : one must

love a babe in peril in the crowds[?] –

Emily, we spent a great day

together.

Have you seen the clear head

to-day? Was it nice, & shining & white

–Speak to me of how this grief is

borne – of the helps[?] that issue from

it.

to us I feel there will be such

blessing, but to our people?

Michael

Vincent’s Challenge

Again the early Communion – this

time we are able to stay for a

whole Mass. In quaint Vincent

Square, Westminster, we meet

Emily – she has the exaltation

throughout her of having been

to Vincent’s Mass – tho’ to her

wild sorrow she was not united

to him in the Holy Communion.

A little crowd gathers at the door

of the Horticultural Hall where

there is a Rose Show and a

sectional meeting of the Congress.

I feel the massed weight of shoulders

round me . . . it presses[?] panic into

one’s flesh. And Emily has no

plan about meeting Michael

in the perilous streets tomorrow –

no plan for common safety. I

turn into stricken misery of

terror over my Love – am

sullen to Emily, & feel a

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 349; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 170r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-349.jpg

[E.C.]

blasphemous sullenness toward the

Procession of our Blessed Lord, that

entails such danger & such

suffering – what an un-

thinking of my little snake-

like wriggles in the clay

with such issues deploying on

the air of Heaven. Shame!

I am pushed into the arms of

the policeman opening the

door. To his ‘Don’t push, don’t

push – there’s plenty of time

& of room!” I reply the

truth humbly “I don’t push –

I am pushed”.

We have airy places in front

of the platform.

Emily whispers “He is here, talking

to . . .” She shows me Vincent

in his clerical cloth, swishing

as with the flashes of a

sworded Cherub on some

lady of Hampstead. W.

He knows we are there – it slips

out, a secret betrayed by his

spiritual adumbration – a

power that expresses, without

the senses being used immediately.

He will neither look nor move[?]

toward us, nor speak with us –

but passes away, till suddenly

we see him speaking with

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 350; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 170v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-350.jpg

[E.C.]

sardonic unction to a confrère

ecclesiastical platform while

a Jesuit Father reads a dull,

but unforgettably instructive

paper on Benediction as the

laymen’s own service, developed

from Saluts to our Lady, &

as much a Lay Compline

as the scapular[?] is a miniature

& the Rosary a miniature

Psalter. FrThurston[?] ended by

pleading that there should be

more variety in the Service – the

people should be taught to sing

more of the great hymns of the

Church.

I watch Vincent –

The subtle imaginative face is

like an appearance of cloud

among[?] the solid fabrics of

flesh that are the faces of

the bishops & others round it.

There are shining planes of

suffering & patience in its

lustre; there are dents of darkness

where the Powers of the Enemy

ambush in the cloud-valley

valleys. It is a face startlingly

like Dante’s in configuration –

the powerful nose, flattened

as if by an adversary’s fist;

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 351; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 171r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-351.jpg

[E.C.]

the full-curved lips, yet slanting

inward, waves sucked by a

passionate whirlpool from their

natural saliency – the hollow

cheek – turning the record of

today into a scripture on

old parchment of the tomb;

the brow burthened – the

eyes . . . well, those belong

wholly to Vincent – They are

troubled, abstract, sensitive

withal to everything fine

& beautiful & holy they rest

upon. His eyes & their effect

on the brow & temples make

his face that of a saint,

while the enemy prowls

round other parts of his

face & leaps up every now

& then in his smile, assaulting

one’s veneration as it leaps

up to linger & hide again.

He has no mirror, but he is

far too imaginative, &, being

imaginative, too personal

not to be conscious in many

of his expressions & the modes

of his eyes & lips & head.

At last he begins his paper on

Eucharistic literature. There is

profound & awful relation between

expressed in The Word – Logos, wh :

thought & challenge to lyrical

The new worship of the

That cruel, feeble Government,

destroyer of all honour &

noble freedom, the right

destroy it! May it perish as

enemies should in its

own confusion!

My lovely lunch . . . no coffee-cup

How I realise what we are

to each other –

“The House is echoless as one were dead”

O little Whymmie! O Little Chow!

Beloved Painter

Michael is well-content the scapular

shd be kept carefully among the

best shirts for the moment. One day,

before a journey, you will wear it

In travelling you are careful

to have your visiting-card about

you. In case of accident those who

search will pick you up & take you

to a good address – in other words

to Lonsdowne House. In like manner

those who pick up your soul,

perceiving the scapular, will,

without further scrutiny,

nip you off to Paradise – consider!

Oh, Painter, it is good you like

the coral! Soon I shall have

exhausted Somerby. Already they

say – of some species – none of

a very good colour remain ! ! !

I have to apologise to Somerby

for the hours I detain him.

Of course the real choice is made

on a breath. “Have you by chance

a coral” & like the sea-man

in your picture, up starts the anxious

Somerby, trembling – with an

offering of coral in his hand.

May she win a critic in

a very near past God found

good on this first resting-day. .

been thankful & like Wordsworth

been left weeping at the gratitude

of those men – instead of which

I was walking on a cloud

of flowers & incence & very giddy

white light.

enclosure of circled roofs, most

Nov. 3rd

And now we have been to

Leicester & returned – the

Circumstances dismal, the

Significance exhilerating.

In the train we read the Matins

at the Fast till there is little

life left in us, reading the

endless psalms to or rather

against the crash in continuity

of the Express. Michael is

keeping her Jejunium – her

eye clearly looks excited

with abstinence. Now & then

between verse & verse of the

desolating psalms I catch

a fire-bush of maple or

cherry in the desolating

central fields of England.

The Wyvern; next door to our

-selves of last visit! A fire!

After coffee & bread & a crumb

or two of cheese, Michael walks

to Holy Cross for Orders. She meets

an ugly, marred clergyman –

Vincent puts away the thought

ourselves with our sins :

God loves & forgives. If we

are mystically bound close

intimate, for we are suffering

after the manner of His suffering

Him.

I confess to lack of Catholic humility

Arthur Symons’ tragedy has

We go early for the 8 o’clock Mass –

What a sight! The Prior is reading

[K.B.]

Dear Miss Hetty.

A little fire, & violets laid thereon;

One thinks of the incense of this offering

as one drinks your tea.

– I am trying to cure myself of the deep-

native joy in gifts – receiving them.

At present it is in me humbug to

announce it is more blessed to give

than to receive

But I shall abstain by & bye.

Meanwhile – irresistible the secret

& deeply pervading exhilaration of that

tea.

It produces faith, & courage, & the prophetic

soul.

We have secured the address & will

go on drinking it for ever!

What sunshine this morning!

And now it is sorrowful winter.

And new Pilgrim dear, is it really the

East with you?

That is the only mortal experience

worth while.

Our good wishes & our love.

Michael.

[E.C.]

for the Divine Office – my

Time has been learning[?] to

work in chains. It is now

December 9th. We began

Office is the great devotion

of the Church herself.”

On the Sat. after my return, I told

Goss how wounded I had been

I let him have his head &

dashing cheer & kindly eyes &

home of redemptive suffering

– for so many of the cases go

out healed – one wants

to say a prayer, as for the

souls in purgatory. It is

a holy place, where the poor

suffer, if possible, to be better,

& to be made physically fit

again for life. Very quiet &

solemn – & so many over-

worked doctors giving their

fine hands & their precious

time as generously to the

poor, as priests do.

There is an exquisite creature

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 405; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 198r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-405.jpg

[E.C.]

Irish Mary[?], in our opthaline[?] Ward,

who has every scapular on her

breast & rosaries, & a loved

Imitation above her head. Her

broad Irish is of the cooing

breadth of doves’ voices : her

eyes are blue & tender as a

baby’s – only that they realise

what a baby only stares at.

Everyone loves her. “I wish

I had her faith!” Goss says.

“Oh, she is a darling!”

he exclaims from his heart,

with smiling[?] glance.

Once by Lucy’s bed a Catholic

woman heard me say how

hard it was to lose beauty,

as we women must when we

grow older “Beauty may go,

but the manner of it remains”.

Pater could not have said

finer truth than this fat[?],

middle-class woman who

had been trained to worship

mysteries. Surely there must

have been a spot of Irish blood

in her – it brings an ultimate

imaginative fineness from a

venerable civilisation, as also

an ultimate infamy[?] from

centuries of savage degeneration

& lives of brute-animals, as far

as earthly conditions are concerned.

Only once Fay has been to see us –

He was sweet as the flower

of the laurel, an innocence

& wealth of ideality about

him, that made one give

thanks at the altar.

He teazed fragrantly – honey

in his laugh over the fact

that Michael had chanced on

the youngest Confessor at the Cathedral.

He imagined a list[?] & a

sacristan “No, madam, we

have nothing younger at present”

He stayed on late & talked much of

his work – finally of his dream

of writing on Don Juan. This

creature of real, remorseless

evil, this tragic gentleman

of Lucifer’s Court has an

infatuating quality over

Fay as a Creator.

He sketched scenes – especially

the return to a deserted home

before the final reception of

the Sat Statue – Desolate,

grand with unwavering

retribution, his eyes, his

head expressed the fate

of the cruel sinner.

There was in Fay’s aspect the

crispness of an element playing

over a surface – wind over a stream

or over ilexes, salt foam over a

[Page]

And I seem to remember when

“outside” I read of[?] monasteries

We have enjoyed this Christmas

The Tuesday before Father Gray came I

It assures him I am not going

meanly away with no gift

To Leicester leaving Christmas at

We speak of the O Antiphons &

is made up of discourses on various

audiences, the gt. prophet-preacher

expounded. Among them, the greatest

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 424; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 207v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-424.jpg

Then Vincent speaks of the wonderful

form of literature given to the

Jews to make preparation for

the Coming of Messiah – prophecy.

All literatures deal mostly with

the Past & net next to that with the

present : prophetic literature deals

entirely with the future. There

is nothing like it in the literature

of the world – not in Greece : for

the likeness of form in some

of Plato’s Vision really masks

an entire difference, for Plato’s

Vision is concerned with ideas –

the Prophetic Visions with

facts to be. Wonderful that

the Eternal Logos – The Word –

gave to literature His own

expression of the plan of

Grace to be.

We retire to mine Host[?]ess[?]’s[?] own

of the idea that creative work

can be done by dropping it &

taking it up again in intervals.

It is so Vincent does his work –

& this fact once for all proves

he has no creative centrality

– but a discursive imagination

& powers of thought that range, but

are [????]⟨limited⟩ by the formalism of

scientific habit & religious discipline.

“Oh, Father, if you are spinning a

web & a hand brushes it – the

web, the delicate structure, the

thing of art, is gone, is demolished”.

He listens, taught & apprehensive.

Then he gives his judgment – then

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 427; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 209r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-427.jpg

[E.C.]

the priest, the religious, trembles

into exception to the judgment.

Again he has been made anxious

over the strain the Divine Office

has laid on me of late.

He proposes that I should,

as a discipline in obedience,

either offer any portion of

the Office unread as a sacrifice

to God, or accept Michael’s

will that I should omit any

portion as a command to be

obeyed for God’s Glory. But

he sees my unwillingness

to introduce any bondage

into a free relation of Love,

& finally he leaves me to

the self-control of the first

course. In the vista of this

debate I hear many hard

things about obedience, &

its perfection – the strength

of will it that [sic] generates &

maintains it, so that, in the

cloister it is considered ‘better

to obey an equal than a

superior – the measure of the

obedience being larger.

Ah me! I left Goscommon laying

down obedience, & I come to

Vincent – & it is obedience again.

Is this my Christmas packet from

the Tree of Life? I don’t like

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 428; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 209v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-428.jpg

[E.C.]

my present, & a deep moroseness

bread & butter – but they

are further on to whom

those to whom only converse

is extended when they come

to a house”.

“But I must not keep you,

Father” – I feel he is getting

anxious from without.

– “No, Child, for it is getting late”.

“You will hear my confession,

Father”.

“The Church is shut & locked”

“Then you cannot hear it?”

“Will you mind making it here?”

With a spasm of terror I answer

“No”.

The mobile form seats itself & becomes

apostolically quiet – the voice

usually so personal, commands

briefly “Kneel there” – the hand

distance of about a quarter of

a yard is indicated.

Above the Visible Confessor, a

jet of unqualified electric light

mimics the Last Judgment.

“Judex ergo cum sedebit

Quidquid latet apparebit”

Notebook 23, Page Image 429; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 210r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-429.jpg

[E.C.]

The violating light that hisses

I bow to the great Sacrament

has chiefly come to it, so

[Page]

display closes like a nightmare

Tuesday – Jan Dec. 22nd

The crowled & elegant Prior is

The Latin is spoken as a

our confusion, & now we

part on a supreme moment

made a supreme agitation.

Poor woman – she was

Anglesea looks a most

The voyage! I never stir my

36Johnnie at Kingston rushes[?] us into

No cheerful Suzane –

Christmas Day

The two last Masses were said

after the Midnight Mass had been

sung – My nearest approach

to Christmas festivity has been

the coffee out of hot cans

at 2 o’clock – the bread &

butter with the coffee. One drainks

the coffee as if it were gift

of Bacchus – the wheaten

bread one is too bewitched to

really eat, but the sight of it

fills the hungry with⟨who have⟩ fasted with

a sense of deliverance.

We retire to short sleep – Michael

has only 3 hours, & faithful to her

dedication rises at a few moments

to 5. I do not go out for any

Mass till 11 o’clock – but we

read the Office to conquer the

disorder its recent length has

caused in our days.

I love the the raising of the

great benignant Host at the

Village Benediction, in front of

the altar Little One has decked[?].

But the day is terribly strained

in this house of religious excess

– the Master was 7 Masses &

10 Benedictions – there is no

peace & the good will is tucked away

from recognition. I hate the

sight of Turkey & plum-pudding –

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 437; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 214r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-437.jpg

[E.C.]

they make my inside feel like a

tomb. And we sleep – & I

presented as if under threat of

‘the faggots’ by John.

I give up at night & withdraw

to the feast of bed. There

reading the office, sleeping

inundating river, that

remain through all the

lovely feast-days after Christmas

I read the Masses day by day

& strive to be in spiritual

union with the a Mass actually

being celebrated – this brings

me to complete following of

each Mass.

While, in bed, ⟨on⟩ the ⟨last of the⟩ five days after

Pennesi[?]. What has become of them?

A telegram sent to the Jesuit Son

It is so strange! – People always

[Page]

[E.C.]

begin doubling God’s Love before

What God has given Himself, in

giving it to His Son, surely we

mortals cannot call cruelty.

At the quick of the mystery of Pain

Revelation springs out with

its live pulses of Love; & to feel

the throb of that fount in the

swirl of anguish is to be religious –

to forget all else but those wondrous

pulses is to be a Saint.

When I am better again & go to

Also the dark is thick – one cannot

read a word of one’s Missal, & there

is something of Faith’s overplus,

superstition, about the atmosphere

Last Day of the Old Year.

In the White Bedroom at Grove House

I have heard from Father Larkin

that I am full of weeds – no

space for flowers to grow; & that

I have been beating about.

making noise & fuss with

my Office & prayers & Masses.

By some supernatural gift

⟨of second sight⟩ he tells me I have been

praying for my friends, & not

for my weedy self – so making

all I do of no effect; because

the real thing is to get

rid in myself of what stops

God’s gardening; & the way

to get rid of the hindrance

is by prayer, unceasing, that

will be sure to be answered.

“You must say your Office in

your own intention to get rid of

pride in all its forms. You must

say your Rosaries or other devotions

for the same intention; you must

hear Mass in the same intention –

& receive Holy Communion for the same.

Then you will have peace – but

never, while the weeds grow, & you

pray for other people. My beloved

Child, if I should see you in

a year’s time after this course

you w d be quite different”.

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 442; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 216v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-442.jpg

[E.C.]

He says all these severe things

with a breath as warm &

healthful as the breath of

kine. & when he ends “You

will be sure to pray for me,

my child?” I find myself replying

“Yes, dear father, I will”.

He asked me before to pray for

him “always”. I have not failed.

Perhaps this simple & amazing

time in the Confessional has

been the hard reward for

my faithful prayers for this

most high Dominican.

I went yesterday to confession

& read my Vespers in the new

Intention. So I have a

religious course to begin the

year with.

And we hear from Tommy & Fr Gray

we have, as Michael Field –

I mean as Signor di Borgia – a

review of Mariamne in the

‘Times” (we have not yet seen

it) wh : Fr Gray says has

been for him “quite an Etiennes[?].

The writer of the article must

know well, for obvious reasons,

who is the poet. The aristocracy

is not such a numerous body.”

And Tommy writes “Now no doubt

all the papers & reviews will

discover Mariamne, as Harold

Child has stood so manfully[?]

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 443; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 217r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-443.jpg

[E.C.]

to his guns. Harrah! Fire away

& let the sales run up!”

So the omens for the great work of

next year are widely auspicious.

Young Signor di Borgia dies – &

And Fr Gray has at last written a

with closed eyes when I have long

to the little Father’s priestly gong!

I am feeling, this day of achy damp,

very despondent – tears just under

my face, because Larkin thinks me

“an unweeded garden,

that runs to seed” in a weird,

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 444; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 217v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-444.jpg

[E.C.]

holy Hamlet-like apercu.

And as I look back over the

year – with its straining vigilance,

its discipline so totally novel

to me, in its untender guidance

by the servants of God, on its

lack of fostering privacy, any

of all this hardship is

“ “Fie!

’Tis an unweeded garden

That runs to seed – things rank

& gross of nature

Possess it merely – that it oh’ – come

Of course I have to say “Yes, they

do possess it – They must be

there; for every holy Father

without exception to find them

exception finds Michael “a dear

little child”.

There is one sort of ultimate comfort

in the fact the holy Fathers all

want to have a special hand

in waving[?] the “Fie!”; & suggesting

or ⟨even⟩ doing the work of gathering

into bundles. So they must have

some expectations to set them

on . . . otherwise I should have

a wholly desert feeling under

[Page]

Notebook 23, Page Image 445; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 218r; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-445.jpg

[E.C.]

the estimate of every man who judges.

Anyhow I am weary & restive

– & have to fight envy of

Michael & her welcome by

every priest the way she is

stroked as ‘a lass unparagoned[?]’,

by the Holy Roman Church.

The one joy of joys has been the daily

grace of Holy Communion with

the Incarnate Word. By that

love all change that has availed

in me has been wrought – by that

love I have been kept to the

discipline & all the hard ways

of sanctification. By that love I

have learnt a mere shadowed bit

of charity; by that love I have

now & then understood the strangest

thing in the world, true humility;

by that love I have made rigorous

confession of sin, & felt the loving

fount that alone has given power

to continue the sublime &

terrifying intercourse with the

Holiest, the wondrous Beloved.

Confirmation was a hidden blessing

– none the less needing from me

a Te Deum : a change of great

might, an inherent patience

of the Most High Spirit of God

that may take years to require

expression.

[E.C.]

The Call to give our Art to Christ &

His Church, expressed, as Angel,

by Vincent at the Eucharistic

Congress, has been the tremendous

climax of the year – what, I

should imagine, was given

as the acclivity to wh : the

year was to tend. I find the

year has worked out very closely

to its prophecies. It has been

full of surprises, & it has lain

between two events of

mountain-eminence to us

– viz. Our Daily Reception of

the Blessed Host beginning the

year, & the call to Sing the

Blessed One at His Eucharistic

Congress at the end of the

year. In the midst & very hidden,

the Sacrament of Confirmation

I have been most rigorously treated by

God & by His priests – even by my Love.

Rigour, rigour!

What Goscommon & Vincent & now

Larkin have been to me, I am not

safe enough from bitterness to write –

they have largely filled the year

with influence & pain & the excitement

of the blowing wind of the Spirit.

Next to their influence has been

the new influence of the Hospital

– the quiet place one enters with

a prayer & the feet that move to

The year has been very poor in gt.

But no book has moved us – I

Exalted mountain-clouds, Earth

No book has moved us, except

Michael has found St John

Fay has been when in Paragon

Friends at the Vineyard – ah, only

And always over the altar the

Always, always Whymmie with

our dear Lord Christ’s teaching us

Here in Ireland I cannot reply

to his radiant presence as well

Now I am going to say a Miserere

our Borgia work –

and I have a sense of wealth –

that this is going to be a rich

year – that novitiate being

done, we shall begin to

come into the heritage for

wh : we have endured.

I feel we shall come into

this possession, not as we

esteem likely – the year

not advancing through surprises

by[?] through revelations &

discoveries. I feel that the

conduct of our wealth

will be in stronger hands

than we think, & we shall

spend in a stronger way

than we imagine

We shall be shown things

this year – this is a more

solid conduct of our spirit

than by astonishing them.

I seem to hear music as

a dominating beauty.

June or a little earlier strikes

on me as if determining much

of the wider manifestation

the year burns with.

Whatever comes to us

will come to us in the

word Behold.

But it is wealth & we must

use it – I feel Behold

is only the passivity of

The year will not be mov[?]

Friendship will be not so

but strangely roused, I

think, in two cases[?].

It will be a year for the eyes &

the wrist.

I feel that the work done

will be unmitigably right –

quite dreadfully right – if

we wait for the revelation . .

& act seasonably to it.

The revelation – then

the efficiency & happiness.

Delay wd be the danger

of the year.

Courage officially inspired

by the Sovereign Spirit of

Counsel, is the daemon.

Wordsworth writes how he suddenly

pure white. I cannot say how much

imagination. My sorrow was controlled &

Altar’s Prayer

“O God! If I worship Thee for fear of Hell,

send me to Hell! & if I worship Thee

in hope of Heaven, deny me Heaven!

but if I worship Thee for Thyself, oh,

withhold not from me the Eternal

Beauty!”

Lo, in His face commingled

Is every claim & grace;

The whole of Beauty singled

Into a perfect face,

Beholding Him wd cry

‘There is no God but He, & He is the most High”

The Egyptian mystic Ibn al Farid

“L’amour des fleurs tient encore une

grande place dans l’esprit de l’ami

que je cherche à peindre. Mais les

fleurs favorites de Baudelaire ne

sont ni la Marguerites, ni l’oeillet,

ni la rose. C’est avec de vifs enthusiasmes

qu’il s’arrète devant des plantes

grasses qui semblent ou des

serpents se jetant sur une

proie, on des herissons accroupis.

Formes tormentées, formes

accusées, tel fut, tel est l’idéal du

poète. Il laisse à d’autres les

Marguerites, en face desquelles

il me tenait dernièrement des

discours mimés pleins de mépris,

ayant éprouvé sans doute des

haut de coeur du méchant emploi

des m’aimes-tu? un peu,

passionnement &c dont ont abusé

les faiseurs de romances.

Ce qui est rouge, voyant, sonore

dentelé, capricieux, Baudelaire

l’a accueilli tout d’abord sans

s’inquieter s’il y avait parfum

à recueillir. Il préfère le dahlia

à la violette. Je ne sourais

mieux expliquer l’homme.”

Champleury dans ses Souvenirs, quoted

by J. Crepet

“S. François de Solas[?]” – Fortunat Strowski. 1898 .

Le Conte de Lisle.

[ “The basal truth is that God is one. The further revelation of

Divine Persons’ explains & expands, but does not contradict

this. The personal distinction in Godhead is a distinction

within, & of, Unity: not a distinction of wh : qualifies unity,

or usurps the place of it, or destroys it . . . we must guard

against being misled by our own experience of personality.

We shd think of the Divine Persons as mutually

inclusive rather than mutually exclusive – laying[?]

others in the positive rather than the negative side.

. . . The relations of the Divine Persons to each other as[?]

mutual rel. – There can be no ⟨most[?]⟩ ⟨mutual⟩ relations between

aspects into wh : Sabellianism degrades the Persons.

Christ is God ⟨not⟩ generically, but identically – for God does

not admit a plural. Christ is man not generically

but identically inclusively – He is not one man

among many – the humanity of the infinite God.

It had a unique capacity for universal relation,

& the means whereby it is realised is His Spirit . . .

Christ is not so much God & Man, as God in & through &

as Man – Incarnate. Through the Holy Spirit grace & peace

come from God to us.

. . .

It is Penitence that atones – a real change, but to simple

human nature impossible in any perfection. Perfect

penitence requires not only contrition for sin, but complete

identity of the Self with the Holiness that condemns

sin – this combination only in Christ, whose death

upon the Cross was as it were a vicarious[?] penitence

perfect in its kind – brought home to the human soul by

the Holy Spirit, transforming it from within, making

the objective subjective, renewing our nature, so that it is

no longer ours but[?] Christ’s, not by distinction of our personality

but by its Communication. Pentecost is the true

compliment of Calvary : Calvary without Pentecost

is not yet in vital relation with ourselves. Its virtue

becomes ours through the indwelling Spirit of Christ.

Christ’s identification with the Judgment of God upon

sin & with the heartfelt contrition that man ought to feel

but cannot adequately feel for it was the most poignant

of all His pangs on Calvary.” Life & Christ. &[?]c[?] Sunday –

Notebook 23, Page Image 456; Vol. XXIII, Add MS 46798, fol. 223v; Holly Laird; add_ms_46798-456.jpg

[E.C.]

Meditation

Et Conceptus est de Spiritu Sancto –

When God the Father, who had begotten His Son before all worlds in His Charity

makes the gt. renunciation & parts with Christ that His Son may be

incarnate as Man the parting is utter. Incarnation means

mediation. The Father may not in His own Person conceive His

Son in the Virgin’s Womb – it is the Work of the Holy Spirit –

& only by the Holy Spirit can He proclaim His Son, only by

an Angel can He support Him from the strain of temptation

or uphold Him in agony. The Passion began before the

human birth of Christ, when the only-begotten of the

Father had to be conceived of the Holy Ghost as a

Man – directness of relation ended. The Son of God, like

His, come under Mediations of the Holy Spirit as we

men come under Mediation of the priest ordained by

Christ to give us His Sacraments. So Christ is

our brother in His Manhood – & the Passion of His

Godhood is of pre-natal reach.
